[{'account_id': 30252, 'date': '2019-04-11 14:20:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-04-11 14:20:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-03 18:58:47.000000000', 'message': 'Migrate migrate  Ubuntu jobs from xenial to Bionic

We have migrated the zuulv3 job to Bionic during Dec/Jan month.
 - http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2018-December/000837.html
 - https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/devstack-bionic
But that effort does not move all gate job to Bionic as there are
large amount of jobs are still legacy jobs. All the legacy jobs still
use Xenial as nodeset.

As per the decided runtime for Stein, we need to test everything on openstack
CI/CD on Bionic - https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html

This commit migrates the Ubuntu jobs to run on bionic.

More Details:
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/legacy-job-bionic
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003614.html

Change-Id: I98d2c562f4bf4980a6e5bcf9fb3f5bf5df664b36

commit_message:
Migrate migrate  Ubuntu jobs from xenial to Bionic

We have migrated the zuulv3 job to Bionic during Dec/Jan month.
 - http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2018-December/000837.html
 - https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/devstack-bionic
But that effort does not move all gate job to Bionic as there are
large amount of jobs are still legacy jobs. All the legacy jobs still
use Xenial as nodeset.

As per the decided runtime for Stein, we need to test everything on openstack
CI/CD on Bionic - https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html

This commit migrates the Ubuntu jobs to run on bionic.

More Details:
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/legacy-job-bionic
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003614.html

Change-Id: I98d2c562f4bf4980a6e5bcf9fb3f5bf5df664b36

commit_message:
helm-toolkit: fix k8s rolebinding bad SA ref

the service account(SA) is created in the release namespace
while the rolebinding references a SA in possibly the wrong
namespace according to the computed `allNamespace` set

Change-Id: I18820981da8d1dcd71f654211ecabc58b699c3a5
Closes-Bug: #1829358
Signed-off-by: ydegat <yann@2kmail.net>

commit_message:
Fix usage of tenant_id in tests

Some tests assume that the base test classes
set a tenant_id parameter at the class level.
This is not the case because base test classes
most often are capable of dealing with multiple
tenants via tempest's test credential framework.

Change-Id: If9b57f0f78c43d5f17738f13cc86b0594d3d2994
Signed-off-by: Goutham Pacha Ravi <gouthampravi@gmail.com>

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it

rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 30385, 'date': '2019-05-07 09:57:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 30385, 'date': '2019-05-07 10:06:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 28101, 'date': '2019-05-07 11:34:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 30385, 'date': '2019-05-09 14:37:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2019-05-14 15:10:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

we use the logic here to get ordered addition of nodes during initial cluster formation: https://github.com/openstack/openstack-helm-infra/blob/master/rabbitmq/templates/bin/_rabbitmq-start.sh.tpl#L44-L60'}, {'account_id': 30385, 'date': '2019-05-16 09:40:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> we use the logic here to get ordered addition of nodes during
 > initial cluster formation: https://github.com/openstack/openstack-helm-infra/blob/master/rabbitmq/templates/bin/_rabbitmq-start.sh.tpl#L44-L60
hi pete,

thank you very much for your review.
my bad. i didn't notice this part of code.

At first glimpse, it's hard for me to get what it's trying to achieve.
if i can have a little chat on freenode with someone so i can get a better understanding of what it does, it would be great.

But still i'm quite confused because on the other hand,
in the official rabbitmq doc regarding peer discovery in kubernetes
(https://www.rabbitmq.com/cluster-formation.html#peer-discovery-k8s), there is this note

```
Lastly, some mechanism rely on ordered node startup provided by the underlying provisioning and orchestration tool. Kubernetes stateful sets is one example of an environment that offers such a guarantee.
```

So it seems to me that they explicitly rely on the statefulset "orderedready" feature.
Don't you think that switching it to "parallel" may be risky ?

The issue i faced (at least in 2nodes clusters), was that the second node discovered the first one, but as it wasn't ready yet, it booted in standalone mode.
with the bash snippet you highlighted, i dont see how to fix that.

+ According to your commit log (https://github.com/openstack/openstack-helm-infra/commit/b5e8c41d2ec362bfe22600e4f5623cf514c5b56f)

switching back to OrderedReady shouldnt invalidate your implementation, am i wrong?'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2020-07-15 20:30:26.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Abandoning since there hasn't been any recent activity, if anyone wants to continue this work, please feel free to restore this."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-07 09:50:08.000000000', 'message': 'Closes-Bug: #1828008

Change-Id: I508e285ee6a467728a764d9d1c11a4195e3c4989
'}, {'created': '2019-05-07 09:57:26.000000000', 'message': 'rabbitmq: switch statefulset podmgmtpolicy to OrderedReady

Closes-Bug: #1828008

Change-Id: I508e285ee6a467728a764d9d1c11a4195e3c4989
'}, {'created': '2019-05-07 10:06:11.000000000', 'message': 'rabbitmq: switch statefulset podmgmtpolicy to OrderedReady

PodManagementPolicy set to "Parallel" can lead to race condition issues.
Especially in the rabbitmq case where, as nodes are launched in parallel
and may haven't reached a certain state, they can't discover each other
and fail to form a cluster.

As this "cluster forming" step isn't retried, each pod node then run in
standalone mode.

Switching back explicitly to the default "OrderedReady" value of
podManagementPolicy solved the issue as the second  & following
nodes start only once the first one is up & ready.

(see doc:  https://www.rabbitmq.com/cluster-formation.html#peer-discovery-k8s)

Closes-Bug: #1828008

Change-Id: I508e285ee6a467728a764d9d1c11a4195e3c4989
'}]
commit_message:
rabbitmq: switch statefulset podmgmtpolicy to OrderedReady

PodManagementPolicy set to "Parallel" can lead to race condition issues.
Especially in the rabbitmq case where, as nodes are launched in parallel
and may haven't reached a certain state, they can't discover each other
and fail to form a cluster.

As this "cluster forming" step isn't retried, each pod node then run in
standalone mode.

Switching back explicitly to the default "OrderedReady" value of
podManagementPolicy solved the issue as the second  & following
nodes start only once the first one is up & ready.

(see doc:  https://www.rabbitmq.com/cluster-formation.html#peer-discovery-k8s)

Closes-Bug: #1828008

Change-Id: I508e285ee6a467728a764d9d1c11a4195e3c4989

commit_message:
Adding EXTRA_CFLAGS="-Ofast" for DPDK and OpenvSwitch comnpilation

As suggested by Intel to improve the performance , the DPDK
And openvswitch should be compiled with EXTRA_CFLAGS="-Ofast"

Change-Id: I149f51a501f0941b2e335662b75f9c9a2d62ebce

(1 comment)

This looks good at first sight, but see my comment. I hope at some point I would be able to simplify the zuul definitions by being more standard. In the meantime, no reason to block this, so still voting positively. A new patchset would be welcomed though.'}, {'account_id': 9963, 'date': '2019-05-09 11:13:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

JP, but the distro name is really OpenSUSE Leap, not just OpenSUSE.

There is also OpenSUSE Tumbleweed for example.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-05-13 10:39:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> JP, but the distro name is really OpenSUSE Leap, not just OpenSUSE.
 > 
 > There is also OpenSUSE Tumbleweed for example.

I would be fine with opensuse_leap15 then.'}, {'account_id': 7102, 'date': '2019-05-14 04:47:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > This looks good at first sight, but see my comment. I hope at some
 > point I would be able to simplify the zuul definitions by being
 > more standard. In the meantime, no reason to block this, so still
 > voting positively. A new patchset would be welcomed though.

 > > JP, but the distro name is really OpenSUSE Leap, not just
 > OpenSUSE.
 > >
 > > There is also OpenSUSE Tumbleweed for example.
 > 
 > I would be fine with opensuse_leap15 then.

But that's also not consistent with ubuntu. The distro is OpenSUSE Leap (Leap is in the distro name, not the version). So opensuse-leap_15 would be an option. But I would prefer opensuse_leap_15 or even better, opensuse_leap_15.0"}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-05-14 10:38:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> > (1 comment)
 > >
 > > This looks good at first sight, but see my comment. I hope at
 > some
 > > point I would be able to simplify the zuul definitions by being
 > > more standard. In the meantime, no reason to block this, so still
 > > voting positively. A new patchset would be welcomed though.
 > 
 > > > JP, but the distro name is really OpenSUSE Leap, not just
 > > OpenSUSE.
 > > >
 > > > There is also OpenSUSE Tumbleweed for example.
 > >
 > > I would be fine with opensuse_leap15 then.
 > 
 > But that's also not consistent with ubuntu. The distro is OpenSUSE
 > Leap (Leap is in the distro name, not the version). So
 > opensuse-leap_15 would be an option. But I would prefer
 > opensuse_leap_15 or even better, opensuse_leap_15.0

it is consistent with ubuntu. ubuntu being ubuntu_xenial it makes sense to me to do opensuse_leap15."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-05-14 10:40:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> > > (1 comment)
 > > >
 > > > This looks good at first sight, but see my comment. I hope at
 > > some
 > > > point I would be able to simplify the zuul definitions by being
 > > > more standard. In the meantime, no reason to block this, so
 > still
 > > > voting positively. A new patchset would be welcomed though.
 > >
 > > > > JP, but the distro name is really OpenSUSE Leap, not just
 > > > OpenSUSE.
 > > > >
 > > > > There is also OpenSUSE Tumbleweed for example.
 > > >
 > > > I would be fine with opensuse_leap15 then.
 > >
 > > But that's also not consistent with ubuntu. The distro is
 > OpenSUSE
 > > Leap (Leap is in the distro name, not the version). So
 > > opensuse-leap_15 would be an option. But I would prefer
 > > opensuse_leap_15 or even better, opensuse_leap_15.0
 > 
 > it is consistent with ubuntu. ubuntu being ubuntu_xenial it makes
 > sense to me to do opensuse_leap15.

I don't want to nit pick for the purpose of nitpicking though. The idea was that we could use the - to split stuff, the _ was to separate if there is multiple version of said os, for example ubuntu_bionic vs ubuntu_xenial. If we decide to have opensuse_tumbleweed / opensuse_leap_15 and opensuse_leap_16 in the (very far) future, that's fine for me too."}, {'account_id': 1091, 'date': '2019-05-14 15:43:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

It seems like a different naming convention which is used for image tag names suffix (i.e. opensuse_15) e.g. https://hub.docker.com/r/openstackhelm/nova/tags

Imho, having Dockerfile name suffix opensuse_15 can help in mapping to image name tag so that its easier to correlate generated image with related dockerfile for a newcomer to a project.

It will be good to have a standard convention (distro_majorVersion) across openstack-helm and airship components images (https://review.opendev.org/#/q/branch:master+topic:airship_suse)'}, {'account_id': 7102, 'date': '2019-05-15 06:08:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

[...]
 > > But that's also not consistent with ubuntu. The distro is
 > OpenSUSE
 > > Leap (Leap is in the distro name, not the version). So
 > > opensuse-leap_15 would be an option. But I would prefer
 > > opensuse_leap_15 or even better, opensuse_leap_15.0
 > 
 > it is consistent with ubuntu. ubuntu being ubuntu_xenial it makes
 > sense to me to do opensuse_leap15.

ubuntu does not have different distros. The schema seems to be $distro_$version . For ubuntu that is ubuntu_xenial (or ubuntu_18.04). For openSUSE, that would be opensuse-leap_15.0 or opensuse-tumbleweed_latest (or something like latest).
Or is $distro_$schema the wrong assumption?"}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-05-16 10:53:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I believe we should not do this now. Instead, we should tag the current images if we think are ready, to the right name, and then update the images. Else it will just break things.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-05-16 13:08:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> I believe we should not do this now. Instead, we should tag the
 > current images if we think are ready, to the right name, and then
 > update the images. Else it will just break things.

(Read that as an administrative -1)'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-05-20 12:38:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

> [...]
 > > > But that's also not consistent with ubuntu. The distro is
 > > OpenSUSE
 > > > Leap (Leap is in the distro name, not the version). So
 > > > opensuse-leap_15 would be an option. But I would prefer
 > > > opensuse_leap_15 or even better, opensuse_leap_15.0
 > >
 > > it is consistent with ubuntu. ubuntu being ubuntu_xenial it makes
 > > sense to me to do opensuse_leap15.
 > 
 > ubuntu does not have different distros. The schema seems to be
 > $distro_$version . For ubuntu that is ubuntu_xenial (or
 > ubuntu_18.04). For openSUSE, that would be opensuse-leap_15.0 or
 > opensuse-tumbleweed_latest (or something like latest).
 > Or is $distro_$schema the wrong assumption?

I understand your point, you're saying the distro is named leap, not that the version is leapX. Wikipedia, THE universal source of truth, states opensuse is the distro, and the latest stable version is "Leap 15". I understand the confusion. But let's not discuss the colour of the shed :)'}, {'account_id': 7102, 'date': '2019-05-20 18:53:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> > [...]
 > > > > But that's also not consistent with ubuntu. The distro is
 > > > OpenSUSE
 > > > > Leap (Leap is in the distro name, not the version). So
 > > > > opensuse-leap_15 would be an option. But I would prefer
 > > > > opensuse_leap_15 or even better, opensuse_leap_15.0
 > > >
 > > > it is consistent with ubuntu. ubuntu being ubuntu_xenial it
 > makes
 > > > sense to me to do opensuse_leap15.
 > >
 > > ubuntu does not have different distros. The schema seems to be
 > > $distro_$version . For ubuntu that is ubuntu_xenial (or
 > > ubuntu_18.04). For openSUSE, that would be opensuse-leap_15.0 or
 > > opensuse-tumbleweed_latest (or something like latest).
 > > Or is $distro_$schema the wrong assumption?
 > 
 > I understand your point, you're saying the distro is named leap,
 > not that the version is leapX. Wikipedia, THE universal source of
 > truth, states opensuse is the distro, and the latest stable version
 > is "Leap 15". I understand the confusion. But let's not discuss the
 > colour of the shed :)

Let's ask the real source of truth :)

# cat /etc/os-release |grep 'NAME\|VERSION'
NAME="openSUSE Leap"
VERSION="15.1 "
VERSION_ID="15.1"
PRETTY_NAME="openSUSE Leap 15.1"
CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:opensuse:leap:15.1"


And now the same on a Tumbleweed machine:

# cat /etc/os-release |grep 'NAME\|VERSION'
NAME="openSUSE Tumbleweed"
# VERSION="20190516"
VERSION_ID="20190516"
PRETTY_NAME="openSUSE Tumbleweed"
CPE_NAME="cpe:/o:opensuse:tumbleweed:20190516"'}, {'account_id': 8749, 'date': '2019-05-21 17:31:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2020-07-15 20:29:40.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Abandoning since there hasn't been any recent activity, if anyone wants to continue this work, please feel free to restore this."}]

commit_message:
Transform jobs into argo workflow steps

1. Created the lifecycle subdirectory
2. For each manifests/_job_xxx.tpl create the correspoding
   lifecycle/steps/_xxx.tpl object
3. Each xxx.tpl contains two sections: container and volumes.
   The corresponding includes can be used in an argo workflow object
4. Add a mockservice to validate the proper template instanciation
   and indentation

Change-Id: I9805ddc8390df65f878fa803ac8ad74ad6507994

subject: Supporting the local time zone
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 8181, 'name': 'Jaesuk Ahn', 'email': 'bluejay.ahn@gmail.com', 'username': 'blujeay.kr'}, {'_account_id': 8898, 'name': 'Chris Wedgwood', 'email': 'cw@f00f.org', 'username': 'anticw'}, {'_account_id': 16513, 'name': 'Seungkyu Ahn', 'email': 'seungkyua@gmail.com', 'username': 'seungkyu'}, {'_account_id': 17068, 'name': 'Jean-Philippe Evrard', 'email': 'openstack@a.spamming.party', 'username': 'evrardjp'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23928, 'name': 'Pete Birley', 'email': 'petebirley@gmail.com', 'username': 'portdirect'}, {'_account_id': 26931, 'name': 'Sungil Im', 'email': 'usnexp@gmail.com', 'username': 'sungil'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 16513, 'date': '2018-12-18 06:39:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 16513, 'date': '2018-12-18 06:41:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

After merging this, I'll change the openstack-helm chart the same way."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-12-19 08:32:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> After merging this, I'll change the openstack-helm chart the same
 > way.

It's probably worth writing code in OSH with a depends-on. I am curious why it's important to have non UTC, as the result might be inconsistent based on images, and might open quite some security trouble (allowing containers to mount time and allow containers to manipulate it can be disastrous in case of security event).

I am not against it (should it pass gates), but I am not really in favor either."}, {'account_id': 16513, 'date': '2018-12-19 10:17:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I also agree to use utc. In Korea, however, there are still people who want to use local time for ease of operation.'}, {'account_id': 16513, 'date': '2018-12-19 10:20:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I tried to create a common function using helm-toolkit, but the part that mounts is only one line, so there seems to be no part to make common code. I want you to let me know if anyone has a good idea.'}, {'account_id': 16513, 'date': '2018-12-19 10:21:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 16513, 'date': '2019-01-04 06:27:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 8898, 'date': '2019-01-04 06:30:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

why?

non utc timezones are confusing on large systems'}, {'account_id': 16513, 'date': '2019-01-04 06:40:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

You're right. But we are using openstack-helm even small or medium-sized systems"}, {'account_id': 8181, 'date': '2019-01-07 04:36:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

As others asked, having non-utc timezone are not an ideal way to operate large system. However, it is sometimes common operational practice to sync everything on korea local time. We should at least give an option to support the local time zone like other openstack deployment method.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-01-07 12:05:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> As others asked, having non-utc timezone are not an ideal way to
 > operate large system. However, it is sometimes common operational
 > practice to sync everything on korea local time. We should at least
 > give an option to support the local time zone like other openstack
 > deployment method.

I understand. For me as long as it's optional and doesn't impact the project negatively, I am good. Waiting for others to chime in."}, {'account_id': 16513, 'date': '2019-01-09 01:59:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2019-01-09 15:30:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 16513, 'date': '2019-01-10 09:37:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 16513, 'date': '2019-01-10 10:49:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2019-01-22 15:04:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 16513, 'date': '2019-01-22 15:52:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2019-02-20 01:18:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

> (1 comment)

I think simply specifying the TZ under the pod key, eg:
```
pod:
  timezone: UTC
```

May suffice here?'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2020-07-15 20:29:32.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Abandoning since there hasn't been any recent activity, if anyone wants to continue this work, please feel free to restore this."}]

commit_message:
Supporting the local time zone

The pod runs by default in the UTC time zone.
To change the time zone to local time, you can change the value of
"pod >> mounts >> timezone >> volumes >> hostPath >> path" to your local area.

Change-Id: Ie582679beb3d8e2dbfcdee730326be2e09db87c6

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-20 09:16:52.000000000', 'message': "fix incorrect ingress name

This PS is to change ingress name from type name to endpoint name.

Now when I use ip address for public endpoint, ingress name
is generated using 'type' for example, when I fix public endpoint
for keystone to ip address, ingress name for keystone is changed
to 'identity' NOT 'keystone'.

Because ingress name is from endpoint type. This PS makes it come
from endpoint name NOT type.

Change-Id: I6377d3e19558a84b75cfc262afdd651942d9b137
"}]
commit_message:
fix incorrect ingress name

This PS is to change ingress name from type name to endpoint name.

Now when I use ip address for public endpoint, ingress name
is generated using 'type' for example, when I fix public endpoint
for keystone to ip address, ingress name for keystone is changed
to 'identity' NOT 'keystone'.

Because ingress name is from endpoint type. This PS makes it come
from endpoint name NOT type.

Change-Id: I6377d3e19558a84b75cfc262afdd651942d9b137

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-08 12:02:43.000000000', 'message': '[DNM] enable just iptables not nftables

Change-Id: Ib3309cbbd6f2ca300ec205528402a3836a6f34df
'}, {'created': '2020-07-08 13:19:26.000000000', 'message': '[DNM] enable just iptables not nftables

Change-Id: Ib3309cbbd6f2ca300ec205528402a3836a6f34df
'}, {'created': '2020-07-08 14:09:02.000000000', 'message': '[DNM] enable just iptables not nftables

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/739994/
Change-Id: Ib3309cbbd6f2ca300ec205528402a3836a6f34df
'}, {'created': '2020-07-09 11:22:00.000000000', 'message': '[DNM] enable just iptables not nftables

iptables rules set in nodepool images for ports
like 22, 19885 are deleted and causing issues in jobs.

This is caused as /etc/sysconfig/iptables is emptied
in tripleo-bootstrap [1] and then nft flush ruleset
removes in memory iptables rules.

Testing by removing nft flush command. Issue is seen
in CentOS8 only.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-ansible/blob/stable/train/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo-bootstrap/tasks/main.yml#L81-L89

Change-Id: Ib3309cbbd6f2ca300ec205528402a3836a6f34df
'}, {'created': '2020-07-10 06:01:25.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "[train/backport] Prevent nftables to interfere with tripleo firewall"

This reverts commit c3b24599d7055c4dead110d25d7479eca7a557fe.

Revert "Do not fail if /usr/sbin/nft is not present"

This reverts commit eedb679db95b281b2be0199d48876b8af64ea3a0.

The nftables rules are not enabled now after [1] so reverting
the original changes which are not needed.

[1] https://git.centos.org/rpms/nftables/c/3730f48

Related-Bug: #1870095
Related-Bug: #1869166
Closes-Bug: #1887112
Change-Id: Ib3309cbbd6f2ca300ec205528402a3836a6f34df
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "[train/backport] Prevent nftables to interfere with tripleo firewall"

This reverts commit c3b24599d7055c4dead110d25d7479eca7a557fe.

Revert "Do not fail if /usr/sbin/nft is not present"

This reverts commit eedb679db95b281b2be0199d48876b8af64ea3a0.

The nftables rules are not enabled now after [1] so reverting
the original changes which are not needed.

[1] https://git.centos.org/rpms/nftables/c/3730f48

Related-Bug: #1870095
Related-Bug: #1869166
Closes-Bug: #1887112
Change-Id: Ib3309cbbd6f2ca300ec205528402a3836a6f34df

[{'created': '2019-05-03 13:19:01.000000000', 'message': 'Usage of rally.conf for services with rally test for debugging

For services with rally test, sometimes its useful to have debug
logging available on client (rally test pod) to traige a failure.

Adding rally.conf as read-only volume mount for rally test pods.
By default debug setting is kept false so no change in existing
behavior of rally test pods.

Adding rally.conf as read-only volume mount for rally test pods.
By default debug setting is kept false so no there is change in

Change-Id: Ic1095acb80fd36604a5012bc877e675c022e18b8

commit_message:
Usage of rally.conf for services with rally test for debugging

For services with rally test, sometimes its useful to have debug
logging available on client (rally test pod) to triage a failure.

Adding rally.conf as read-only volume mount for rally test pods.
By default debug setting is kept false so no there is change in
existing behavior of rally test pods.

Change-Id: Ic1095acb80fd36604a5012bc877e675c022e18b8

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-12 14:59:25.000000000', 'message': 'WIP/DNM Implement argo workflows into the keystone chart

This PS guts out all of the jobs used to deploy keystone and replaces
them with an argo DAG. This dramatically simplifies dependency control
and flow through the deployment, as well as providing the control
structures from the argo toolkit.

This PS is _very_ early in development, and is still missing many of the
features and settings of the original. Further, this PS only minimally
uses the helm-toolkit, and much of the deployment is "hard-coded"

Finally, this PS depends on a new docker image for the
kubernetes-entrypoint tool. It therefore also depends on some changes to
the helm-toolkit. Those changes can be found here:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/634037/

Change-Id: I41703abee3cb2fc4dd2eaa5b2f90a48d32b2c5e5

'}, {'created': '2019-04-17 20:46:34.000000000', 'message': 'WIP/DNM Implement argo workflows into the keystone chart

This PS guts out all of the jobs used to deploy keystone and replaces
them with an argo DAG. This dramatically simplifies dependency control
and flow through the deployment, as well as providing the control
structures from the argo toolkit.

This PS also adds the backup path through a keystone deployment. In
other words, if a database exists for keystone prior to a deployment
(i.e. in the case of an upgrade), that database will be backed up before
the installation. If no such database exists, the backup step is
skipped.

Note that this PS only minimally uses the helm-toolkit, and much of the
deployment is "hard-coded". The helm-toolkit usage will be reintroduced
when it is deemed necessary.

Finally, this PS depends on a new docker image for the
kubernetes-entrypoint tool. It therefore also depends on some changes to
the helm-toolkit. Those changes can be found here:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/634037/

Change-Id: I41703abee3cb2fc4dd2eaa5b2f90a48d32b2c5e5
Depends-On: If4166749085522ee0f10fa673d9fa36094091baa
'}, {'created': '2019-04-18 15:10:24.000000000', 'message': 'WIP/DNM Implement argo workflows into the keystone chart

commit_message:
WIP/DNM Implement argo workflows into the keystone chart

This PS guts out all of the jobs used to deploy keystone and replaces
them with an argo DAG. This dramatically simplifies dependency control
and flow through the deployment, as well as providing the control
structures from the argo toolkit.

This PS also adds the backup path through a keystone deployment. In
other words, if a database exists for keystone prior to a deployment
(i.e. in the case of an upgrade), that database will be backed up before
the installation. If no such database exists, the backup step is
skipped.

Note that this PS only minimally uses the helm-toolkit, and much of the
deployment is "hard-coded". The helm-toolkit usage will be reintroduced
when it is deemed necessary.

Finally, this PS depends on a new docker image for the
kubernetes-entrypoint tool. It therefore also depends on some changes to
the helm-toolkit. Those changes can be found here:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/634037/

Change-Id: I41703abee3cb2fc4dd2eaa5b2f90a48d32b2c5e5
Depends-On: Idc405a723b98ac62285d7dfad1c5ddc8482e6344
Signed-off-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>

subject: Add dnsmasq chart

this looks food to me overall, though I wonder if better suited to osh-addons, or even being incorporated within the ironic chart?'}, {'account_id': 29954, 'date': '2019-03-26 13:41:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> this looks food to me overall, though I wonder if better suited to
 > osh-addons, or even being incorporated within the ironic chart?

first of all thanks for the review! From my point of view dnsmasq shouldn't be moved to osh-addons or incorporated with ironic chart because of the fact that dnsmasq can be used as standalone chart regardless whether it's introduced like a part of ironic standalone ability.

@Pete: I have another question - currently there is used dnsmasq image from my  dockerhub repo. Should i suggest patch for osh-image to use an image from upstream or it's is supposed to be changed by used who is going to deploy it?"}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-03-28 15:57:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

 > used who is going to deploy it?

commit_message:
Print logs of crashed pods

When a pod is not able to start and is in status CrashLoopBackOff, the
CI does not provide the logs and thus it is difficult to troubleshoot.
This patch prints the logs of the pods in that state

Change-Id: Ia4cd168a3f9fd60b5cd10b5900ba2f47235d4815
Signed-off-by: Manuel Buil <mbuil@suse.com>

This is the first iteration for upstream swift charts for
openstack-helm. These charts are very VMware specific, they will
be modified to najethem more generic for the upstream. This review

commit_message:
[DNM][WIP] Adding Swift charts for openstack-helm

This is the first iteration for upstream swift charts for
openstack-helm. These charts are very VMware specific, they will
be modified to najethem more generic for the upstream. This review
is only to serve as a blueprint for the swift integration.

Change-Id: I5e3e1069413aca1f6f5aa883b060a714f8207f37

commit_message:
Add docker-default apparmor profile for elasticsearch.

1. Remove docker-default apparmor profile from
   elasticsearch/values.yaml
2. Add docker-default apparmor profile as deployment jobs.
   add tools/deployment/apparmor/090-elasticsearch.sh

Change-Id: I995348d63a82c9bc45e394734dc6264350c0da26

Add docker-default apparmor profile for elasticsearch.

Remove docker-default apparmor profile from
  elasticsearch/values.yaml
Add docker-default apparmor profile as deployment jobs.
  add tools/deployment/apparmor/046-elasticsearch.sh

Co-authored-by: rj2083@att.com

subject: MariaDB Backup Script
messages:
[{'account_id': 28848, 'date': '2019-01-29 20:23:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28848, 'date': '2019-01-30 13:47:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2019-01-30 13:49:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

why do we need an image for this? could we not use the same image as the server, and mount the script in via a configmap? also it would be nice to see this running as a Cron job.'}, {'account_id': 28848, 'date': '2019-01-30 14:04:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The script can be placed anywhere you would like and used any way you see fit.  In discussing with Scott, he suggested simply placing this work up so a discussion can be started.  Someone else may need to pick this work up and continue with it.'}, {'account_id': 28848, 'date': '2019-01-30 15:51:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 28848, 'date': '2019-02-21 21:12:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 28848, 'date': '2019-02-22 13:22:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 8898, 'date': '2019-04-22 05:17:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Patch Set 5 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2020-07-15 20:14:39.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

subject: This is the first change to explore the system
messages:
[{'account_id': 30120, 'date': '2019-04-16 20:25:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-04-16 20:25:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 30120, 'date': '2019-04-16 20:31:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2020-07-15 20:14:29.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Abandoning since there hasn't been any recent activity, if anyone wants to continue this work, please feel free to restore this."}]

commit_message:
[RFC/DNM] [Calico] Show objects as they are applied

This shows (kubectl -n kube-system logs calico-settings-abcdef) the
calico resource objects before they are applied in the settings job.
The intent here is to allow easier debugging should something not be
working as expected.

Change-Id: I9cb4774c57bf2d6dfc4a17efd37c32fcb12d7a75

will be created as logical volumes. Volumes created by ceph-disk
are still supported.

'}, {'created': '2019-01-31 01:42:45.000000000', 'message': '[CEPH] Switch to using ceph-volume for ceph-osd chart

With the Mimic release, ceph-disk is deprecated. Switch to using
ceph-volume in lieu of this. Going forward new or replaced OSDs
will be created as logical volumes. Volumes created by ceph-disk
are still supported as legacy mount only devices.

'}, {'created': '2019-02-01 21:23:34.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] [CEPH] Switch to using ceph-volume for ceph-osd chart

With the Mimic release ceph-disk is considered deprecated and
will be removed in future Ceph releases.

- Refactor the ceph-helm chart code to use ceph-volume, new or
replaced physical OSDs will be created as logical volumes.
- Existing volumes created by ceph-disk are still supported, but
will only be provisioned when using journal files.
- Remove udev specific code that was required for ceph-disk.
- Ensure the clean up (disk_zap) function can handle logical
volumes and purge them in the correct order.
- Currently only Filestore OSDs are supported.

Change-Id: I49aeddfc0ba2c0f7d56ad578a9c1248204886d6a

'}, {'created': '2019-02-05 17:16:28.000000000', 'message': '[CEPH] Switch to using ceph-volume for ceph-osd chart

With the Mimic release ceph-disk is considered deprecated and
will be removed in future Ceph releases. The replacement
solution is ceph-volume, with provisioned LVM disks.

- Refactor the ceph-helm chart code to use ceph-volume so that new
or replaced physical OSDs will be created as logical volumes
- Existing volumes created by ceph-disk are still supported, but
will only be provisioned when using directory based journals with
a block OSD
- Remove udev specific code that was required for ceph-disk use
cases
- Ensure the clean up (disk_zap) function is more robust and can
handle logical volumes and purge them in the correct order
- Standardize the output messages based on severity

Currently only Filestore OSDs with a directory based, co-located or
non-colocated journals will work with this code.

Change-Id: I49aeddfc0ba2c0f7d56ad578a9c1248204886d6a
'}, {'created': '2019-02-09 00:06:56.000000000', 'message': "[CEPH] Switch to using ceph-volume for ceph-osd chart

With the Mimic release ceph-disk is considered deprecated and
will be removed in future Ceph releases. The replacement
solution is ceph-volume, with provisioned LVM disks.

- Refactor the ceph-helm chart code to use ceph-volume so that new
or replaced physical OSDs will be created as logical volumes
- Existing volumes created by ceph-disk are still supported, but
will only be provisioned when using directory based journals with
a block OSD
- Remove udev specific code that was required for ceph-disk use
cases
- Ensure the clean up (disk_zap) function is more robust and can
handle logical volumes and purge them in the correct order
- In addition to checking the cluster's FSID, we also check the OSD
FSID to ensure the OSD belongs to the cluster. For CI/CD sites
re-using the same FSID, this will allow the Ceph chart to
automatically detect whether or not it needs to zap the disk before
hand (provided OSD_FORCE_REPAIR set)
- Standardize the output messages based on severity

Currently only Filestore OSDs with a directory based, co-located or
non-colocated journals will work with this code.

Change-Id: I49aeddfc0ba2c0f7d56ad578a9c1248204886d6a

"}, {'created': '2019-02-12 16:08:04.000000000', 'message': '[CEPH] Switch to using ceph-volume for ceph-osd chart

With the Mimic release ceph-disk is considered deprecated and
will be removed in future Ceph releases. The replacement
solution is ceph-volume, with provisioned LVM disks.

- Refactor the ceph-helm chart code to use ceph-volume so that new
or replaced physical OSDs will be created as logical volumes
Existing volumes created by ceph-disk are still supported, and will
automatically be managed by ceph-volume

- Remove udev specific code that was required for ceph-disk use
cases

- Ensure the clean up (disk_zap) function is more robust and can
handle logical volumes and purge them in the correct order

- Standardize the output messages based on severity

The use of directory type journals with a block OSD device is now
considered deprecated. File/directory journals are not supported
in ceph-volume, and support for this feature be removed in later
releases. Note that we are only supporting Filestore in these
charts, Bluestore is _not_ expected to work.

Change-Id: I49aeddfc0ba2c0f7d56ad578a9c1248204886d6a

commit_message:
[CEPH] Switch to using ceph-volume for ceph-osd chart

With the Mimic release ceph-disk is considered deprecated and
will be removed in future Ceph releases. The replacement
solution is ceph-volume, with provisioned LVM disks.

- Refactor the ceph-helm chart code to use ceph-volume so that new
or replaced physical OSDs will be created as logical volumes
Existing volumes created by ceph-disk are still supported, and will
automatically be managed by ceph-volume

- Remove udev specific code that was required for ceph-disk use
cases

- Ensure the clean up (disk_zap) function is more robust and can
handle logical volumes, dev mapped devices and purge them in the
correct order

- Standardize the output messages based on severity

The use of directory type journals with a block OSD device is now
considered deprecated. File/directory journals are not supported
in ceph-volume, and support for this feature will be removed in
later releases.

Change-Id: I49aeddfc0ba2c0f7d56ad578a9c1248204886d6a

commit_message:
Neutron: Use socket to communicate with OvS

This PS moves to use a socket for neutron interaction with OvS,
as IP based interaction has proved to be unreliable in some
circumstances.

Change-Id: I7d6be211f9f8494dfdb85531974ae4a633380a84
Signed-off-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>

This patch adds support for iSCSi and FC storage for Nova and
Cinder.

Note: The patch doesn't include any image or image build for Nova

commit_message:
Nova + Cinder: Add iSCSI and FC support

This patch adds support for iSCSi and FC storage for Nova and
Cinder.

Note: The patch doesn't include any image or image build for Nova
and Cinder. It is also necessary to mount some volumes
(ie: /etc/multipath.conf, /etc/iscsi/initiatorname.iscsi) by overriding
values in values.yaml.

Change-Id: I80bb8e4fc3cb1e48fabf7693cde902d847f18b84

commit_message:
[CEPH] Ensure ceph-rbd-pool job runs with MON IPs

Modify the script that runs this job, to use the MON endpoint IPs
and not DNS. This aligns with ithe other charts during initial
cluster formation.

Change-Id: I3029fef1cc3cc13ebcb6697a82f748e4a9988b1c

commit_message:
WIP: add Manila Chart

This PS add Manila Chart with the follwing restrictions:
 * Supports Pike only
 * Only CephFS native driver tested
 * manila-data service for copying, share migration or backup is not supported
 * Modified manila-share from Kolla image required
  - LOCI does not have manila images
  - ceph-common packages is missing in the Kolla manila-share:pike image

Change-Id: I558320263657759d8281db9e8f298b7ed46c5e9d
Story: 2005154
Task: 29869

subject: Optimize SERVICE_TYPE calculation logic
messages: [{'account_id': 25562, 'date': '2019-01-24 07:36:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2020-07-15 20:07:57.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned\n\nAbandoning since there hasn't been any recent activity, if anyone wants to continue this work, please feel free to restore this."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-01-24 07:36:00.000000000', 'message': 'Optimize SERVICE_TYPE calculation logic

For special cases like when the pod is for testing cinder services,
RALLY_ENV_NAME will be "cinder" and then SERVICE_TYPE will be messed
up since output from "rally deployment check" will contain 3 cinder
service records for some environments:
| cinder      | volume                  | Available |
| cinderv2    | volumev2                | Available |
| cinderv3    | volumev3                | Available |
In this case, SERVICE_TYPE will be "volumevolumev2volumev3", which will not
with work with "rally verify start" command in the next line since no tempest
tests will match pattern "tempest.api.volumevolumev2volumev3*".

This patch excludes the service records with version suffix so SERVICE_TYPE
will be calculated correctly for the aforementioned cases.

Change-Id: I984bcd723a4bb1fb27dab7fbe0e9cd977cc23b99
'}]
commit_message:
Optimize SERVICE_TYPE calculation logic

For special cases like when the pod is for testing cinder services,
RALLY_ENV_NAME will be "cinder" and then SERVICE_TYPE will be messed
up since output from "rally deployment check" will contain 3 cinder
service records for some environments:
| cinder      | volume                  | Available |
| cinderv2    | volumev2                | Available |
| cinderv3    | volumev3                | Available |
In this case, SERVICE_TYPE will be "volumevolumev2volumev3", which will not
with work with "rally verify start" command in the next line since no tempest
tests will match pattern "tempest.api.volumevolumev2volumev3*".

This patch excludes the service records with version suffix so SERVICE_TYPE
will be calculated correctly for the aforementioned cases.

Change-Id: I984bcd723a4bb1fb27dab7fbe0e9cd977cc23b99

commit_message:
Cinder : support multi rbd backend

This PS supports cinder multi rbd backend function and refactor mainfests
for cinder backup.
And this PS needs ceph.conf files for each rbd backends and cinder-backup
ceph backend.

* removed external ceph values for cinder backup
* added secret names for each rbd backends
* added ceph client secret keyrings for each rbd backends
* seperated target ceph of cinder-backup and cinder-volume
* changed value name pool_chunk_size -> pool_pg_num

Change-Id: I74d619f33a66ac517660781e7faed6467c8ad938

Updating nova-placement-api to work with opensuse based image

component to work with opensuse based images.
Also adding conf file for allowing access to cgi script in opensuse
environment.

(7 comments)

There is a change in the template or values, which means a different interface for the deployers. That means, for me, that we need to ship a release note (that alone deserves a -1).

Please also see my other comments in the review:
- The commit message needs refactoring
- An explanation about the decisions for the configmap should be explicit

Did we discuss the approach with cores here?
They might have a good solution on how to be flexible with templating per distros.'}, {'account_id': 23928, 'date': '2019-02-01 14:17:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

> (7 comments)
 > 
 > There is a change in the template or values, which means a
 > different interface for the deployers. That means, for me, that we
 > need to ship a release note (that alone deserves a -1).
 > 
 > Please also see my other comments in the review:
 > - The commit message needs refactoring
 > - An explanation about the decisions for the configmap should be
 > explicit
 > 
 > Did we discuss the approach with cores here?
 > They might have a good solution on how to be flexible with
 > templating per distros.

I agree with JP on many of these points - i think this work would also really benefit from a spec, so we can support multiple distros with ease and not end up with sprawl across the charts. Additionally - if we took a firmer grip on the apache config used then we may be able in this case to bypass the distro specific directory layout - and explicitly define the full configuration used by the process - meaning that the only change required would be in the start script to determine the correct binary name to call.'}, {'account_id': 1091, 'date': '2019-02-04 18:17:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Updating keystone-api to work with opensuse based image

Modifiying apache vhosts file location for keystone-api wsgi
component to work with opensuse based images.
Also adding conf file for allowing access to cgi script in opensuse
environment.

Change-Id: I3e49fb7cdb5f84060d9a7b580589b461de201c23

quick test of this now, i see we're not doing right right rbac stuffs if the artifactory pod is in a different namespace to the database:

Entrypoint WARNING: 2018/09/14 03:32:47 entrypoint.go:70: Resolving dependency Service mariadb in namespace openstack failed: endpoints "mariadb" is forbidden: User "system:serviceaccount:cicd:artifactory-db-init" cannot get endpoints in the namespace "openstack" .'}, {'account_id': 8898, 'date': '2018-09-14 03:34:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 62:

something else i noticed, the artifactory-0 pod comes up before the artifactory-db-init completes, we need to add an init dependency for that'}, {'account_id': 8898, 'date': '2018-09-14 03:35:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 62:

i was able to get this up and able to test the web UI without keystone integration working

it's not clear to be what that barrier for merge should be in this case, i'm tempted to say we merge as-is, get a gate in place then iterate to fix it rather than leave it out there any longer

thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 28996, 'date': '2018-09-21 14:42:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 64.'}, {'account_id': 8898, 'date': '2019-01-14 08:01:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 65: Patch Set 64 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 28208, 'date': '2019-02-12 18:38:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 65:

commit_message:
ReadinessProbe_Neutron_agents
This implementation is to add Readiness Probe for neutron agents(l3/
dhcp/metadata). The goal is to make sure the neutron agents related 
processes are up and the tcp sockets to the Rabbitmq are in 
"ESTABLISHED" status. This is done by mining the /proc filesystem on the
guest.

Change-Id: I2d361b9dd1bbde44909ee06936f47fb54104cd7b

commit_message:
Rabbitmq: Path correction for docker-entrypoint.sh to '/usr/local/bin' from '/'

It has been observed that rabbitmq pod ends with crashloopbackoff as 
unable to find docker-entrypoint.sh in '/' during execution of 
rabbitmq-start.sh script

Change-Id: I2ffda7872698cd75b84a009b4542caf7529f7630

commit_message:
Do-not run nginx as root for Ingress helm chart

Modified the Ingress helm chart to ensure that nginx is
not having root level permission.
UID 33 is used to set the ngnix pod to run with www-data user.
Change-Id: I9a0cad4ded75b19d41a8c2da8d65f38e1a40dff1

commit_message:
[DNM] [toolkit]: use explicit full path /kubernetes-entrypoint

Remove the resetting of PATH as this is no longer needed.

Update nagios to use latest entrypoint container.

Change-Id: I0a639364a9ea53c1467967ed4a69065f4d6f84d4

[DNM] experiment: alternate entrypoint container

This alternate entrypoint container differs in that:

 * it's smaller

 * does (capped) exponential back-off when dependencies are not met

 * logging trimmed of unnecessary text

	      /`·.¸

commit_message:
[DNM] experiment: alternate entrypoint container

This alternate entrypoint container differs in that:

 * it's smaller

 * does (capped) exponential back-off when dependencies are not met

 * logging trimmed of unnecessary text

	      /`·.¸
	     /¸...¸`:·
	 ¸.·´  ¸   `·.¸.·´)
	: © ):´;      ¸  {
	 `·.¸ `·  ¸.·´\`·¸)
	     `\\´´\¸.·´

Change-Id: I3b78f64f93a5e9d926a0f5fad9056b1466c6dcb7

Also suggest running tempest tests to help insure that nothing was missed. I did this for cinder and that's how I realized that I missed the glance change."}, {'account_id': 28592, 'date': '2018-12-10 17:34:03.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Code-Review+1 by Mike Pham <tpham0630@gmail.com>
'}, {'account_id': 28592, 'date': '2018-12-10 17:39:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 20466, 'date': '2018-12-11 03:48:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

These network policy patches could use some tests.  My understanding though was that since a lot of neutron and nova pods are running in host mode, the network policy couldn't be enforced at the k8s level."}, {'account_id': 27455, 'date': '2018-12-18 13:16:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8898, 'date': '2019-01-14 20:13:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 27977, 'date': '2019-01-16 13:15:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Can you please update this commit with the tests?'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2020-07-15 20:05:25.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This PS updates the ingress rules for horizon to prevent the

commit_message:
Horizon: Enforce some headers via ingress

This PS updates the ingress rules for horizon to prevent the
browser from doing mime type sniffing (if supported/respected) and
also not load embedded iframes.

Change-Id: I0b16837abdbedba36971a6c6f21ae2e28579e1c7
Signed-off-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>

messages:
[{'account_id': 28848, 'date': '2018-12-06 15:08:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28235, 'date': '2018-12-07 14:47:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 19391, 'date': '2018-12-07 15:54:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I am just wondering about the directory name.  Could that be just "ozone" and have "ozonedb" or "ozonedb-init" under it?  I am thinking you have more stuff in the future for ozone addons, not just db.'}, {'account_id': 28848, 'date': '2018-12-07 16:30:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> I am just wondering about the directory name.  Could that be just
 > "ozone" and have "ozonedb" or "ozonedb-init" under it?  I am
 > thinking you have more stuff in the future for ozone addons, not
 > just db.

I am thinking it will break down like Ranger seems to.  There will be a DB component that installs separate from the app, an API piece and a Collector piece.  But, I'm open to structuring the directories however.'}, {'account_id': 28701, 'date': '2019-01-02 19:13:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Are there plans to make all of ozone in openstack-helm-addons? Seems odd to only have the database init here.'}, {'account_id': 28848, 'date': '2019-01-02 20:44:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Are there plans to make all of ozone in openstack-helm-addons?
 > Seems odd to only have the database init here.

Yes.  The MaraiDB Build will be accomplished with an Armada chart.  Other pieces of Ozone will have components that should eventually end up in openstack-helm-addons.'}, {'account_id': 28701, 'date': '2019-01-02 20:48:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2020-07-15 20:04:20.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

commit_message:
Add possibility to run postgres with TLS

If postgres is configured with TLS also forbid TLS<1.2 and
require it for all connections.

commit_message:
[Ceph-client, ceph-osd] Update helm test

The PS updates helm test and replaces "expected_osds" variable
by the amount of OSDs available in the cluster (ceph-client).
Also the PS updates the logic of calculation of minimum amount of OSDs.

Change-Id: Ic8402d668d672f454f062bed369cac516ed1573e

subject: docs: Adding Ceph Operations Documentation
messages:
[{'account_id': 29528, 'date': '2018-11-28 20:57:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-11-28 20:58:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 29528, 'date': '2018-11-29 08:15:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 29528, 'date': '2018-11-29 09:28:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 29268, 'date': '2018-11-30 02:11:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 29528, 'date': '2018-11-30 12:43:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 17591, 'date': '2018-11-30 15:43:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Before reviewing the rest of the content, the alerting documentation needs to be revisited. The documentation supplied here makes reference to plugins that aren't included in the Nagios image we use for the chart, as we simply use Nagios to query Prometheus for any alerts that Prometheus has raised based on the metrics it gathers. Also, it seems the alerting documentation here is just a copy/paste job of the documentation that exists in the ceph/ceph-nagios-plugins repository. The documentation here should just simply redirect others there instead."}, {'account_id': 29528, 'date': '2018-11-30 19:04:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2020-07-15 20:00:58.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Abandoning since there hasn't been any recent activity, if anyone wants to continue this work, please feel free to restore this."}]

commit_message:
Building images for queens release of openstack services

Now building base image using openstack loci logic which has distro
specific base image build step.

And then that locally built base image is used as FROM value for other
openstack services.
Added support for building loci images locally and publishing to local
docker registry server for testing and verification.
For local image building and publishing, set env variables
export USE_LOCAL_LOCI=true
export TARGET_REGISTRY_BASE=192.168.86.236:5000/openstackhelm

If want to use local copy of loci code, then set
export USE_LOCAL_LOCI=true
export LOCAL_REPO_URI=<local_clone_path_parent_dir>/loci

This has been tested to build images for opensuse leap 15 distro.

Change-Id: I0eafcb74edca9bde49b263ba8f1b4498accb09cc

commit_message:
Post deployment cephx capabilities update

This change is intended to introduce a new step
in the libvirt and gnocchi POD initialization in
order to align the cephx capabilities of a previously
deployed cluster during an upgrade/update procedure.

A helm-toolkit template is created for easy calling
as ceph-update-keyring. It requires the client.admin
keyring to be available for the command to succeed.
The template requires 2 env variables pointing
to the Ceph user name and the Ceph pool if required.

e.g. Early deployments assigned 'allow *' for both
MON and OSD capabilities that were later restricted
to provide a better security.

Change-Id: Id0cc9f4b6babc1411e2a722a0dd7f65b55456c67

commit_message:
Add yp validation dependency into pull-images

The pull-images.sh bash script uses the yp python module to operates.
This change adds a validation to which ensures that the module is
installed on the system.

commit_message:
WIP: restore local image registry functionality

Rot has set in for the local image restory function, this resolves that
by adding gating and also:
 * adding cross namespace perms to the k8s entrypoint functions
 * fixing charts

Change-Id: I0db0a417fe3d70605aa199efc2b81851901d9ba6
Signed-off-by: Pete Birley <pete@port.direct>

Update the default service CIDR configuration

It is 10.96.0.0/12 instead of 10.96.0.0/16 in code.
It cost me much time to find out where to change the configruation, and
add this guide in document.

@James Gu'}, {'account_id': 24580, 'date': '2018-08-14 20:56:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28372, 'date': '2018-08-29 15:06:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

cant we simply use ceph-provisioners chart directly  to use external ceph cluster ?

i think only dependency for it is to have admin keyring of external ceph cluster  , if we have admin keyring we need to create two secrets as shown below and then running ceph  prov chart will do the job, please correct me if i am wrong .

ceph-client-admin-keyring

[client.admin]
  key = AQC2sYZbAAAAABAA/lfOMCpLAZqnVaMyn3cIeA==
  auid = 0
  caps mds = "allow"
  caps mon = "allow *"
  caps osd = "allow *"
  caps mgr = "allow *"

"pvc-ceph-conf-combined-storageclass"

AQC2sYZbAAAAABAA/lfOMCpLAZqnVaMyn3cIeA=='}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2018-09-20 09:23:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 21830, 'date': '2018-09-27 00:28:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 21830, 'date': '2018-09-27 00:33:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

@chinasubbareddy mallavarapu
To use an existing installed ceph, ceph-provisioners only create ceph.conf, not secret. The ceph secret key is specified in values.yaml for services such as cinder or glance.'}, {'account_id': 21830, 'date': '2018-09-27 00:37:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 24580, 'date': '2018-09-27 23:43:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

Thanks for making the names configurable. Following the question on the ceph provisioner chart, on the default path that OSH deploys Ceph, the provisioner chart also deploys the rbd provisioner, storage classes. Did you deploy the rbd provisioner pod outside of the OSH? Kube controller manager by default doesn't install rbd provisioner. I just started to figure out if I could run the OSH ceph provisioner chart to install more than just the ceph.conf, i.e., to also install the rbd provisioner, and storage classes. If works, I will come back to this doc to provide update. Any thoughts on that approach?"}, {'account_id': 21830, 'date': '2018-10-04 00:44:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

@James Gu: I didn't deploy rbd provisioner pod outside of the OSH in this case. I just create a storageclass. Installing the rbd provisioner seems to be a matter of choice."}, {'account_id': 24580, 'date': '2018-10-11 00:59:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1

LGTM. The Kubeadm k8s controller manager seems to miss a Ceph binary file and the out of tree ceph rbd provisioner fixes the issue. Did you run 030-ceph.sh?'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2020-07-15 19:58:37.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Abandoning since there hasn't been any recent activity, if anyone wants to continue this work, please feel free to restore this."}]

A guide on how to integrate existing ceph with OSH without
installing ceph through OSH.

Story: 2003082

[libvirt] Expose parameters to allow overrides

This patch set will create a new file to override the params in
libvirt chart.

messages:
[{'account_id': 27455, 'date': '2018-10-04 14:23:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-10-04 14:23:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 8898, 'date': '2018-10-04 20:27:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

what's the motivation for this?"}, {'account_id': 27455, 'date': '2018-10-04 20:35:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 27455, 'date': '2018-10-05 10:57:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 27455, 'date': '2018-10-05 11:10:44.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to libvirt_listen'}, {'account_id': 27455, 'date': '2018-10-05 14:42:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

> what's the motivation for this?

This recommendation is coming out of libvirt best security practices. This will provide flexibility to include or exclude --listen."}, {'account_id': 27455, 'date': '2018-10-09 13:38:07.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Workflow-1 by Achal <achal9256@gmail.com>
'}, {'account_id': 27455, 'date': '2018-10-09 13:52:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 27455, 'date': '2018-10-09 15:46:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 22477, 'date': '2018-10-09 22:14:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I'm not too familiar with this option - can you please share a link to the security recommendation here as background?  Does libvirt continue to work as expected in OSH with the feature turned off, or would that require additional work?"}, {'account_id': 20466, 'date': '2018-10-09 22:52:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> I'm not too familiar with this option - can you please share a link
 > to the security recommendation here as background?  Does libvirt
 > continue to work as expected in OSH with the feature turned off, or
 > would that require additional work?

Some work will need to be done to ensure the socket-based communication works for libvirt.  I believe this patch is here to allow us to disable "--listen" later so we dont need to listen on tcp ports anymore.'}, {'account_id': 27455, 'date': '2018-10-10 07:20:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 27455, 'date': '2018-10-10 14:57:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 21420, 'date': '2020-07-15 19:58:26.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Abandoning since there hasn't been any recent activity, if anyone wants to continue this work, please feel free to restore this."}]

commit_message:
Libvirt: Make --listen a configurable paramter for libvirtd

This patch set is to make --listen option a configurable parameter
for Libvirt pod while starting libvirt daemon, libvirtd.

The default option will be "--listen".

Change-Id: Ia8d8012e70c9b11c67d9db0d1c8f145ffb5af1d4

commit_message:
Remove incorrect configuration items of heat.conf

heat will run into error when creating keystonclient with both
project_name and trust info, if set "reauthentication_auth_method=trusts"
That's because keystoneauth can not determine what kind scope token heat want.

It has been fixed in heat:[1](more details could be found)

[1]:https://bugs.launchpad.net/heat/+bug/1526293

Change-Id: Icb4507ec32857c15b29e7da374ae31d60895b01a

commit_message:
Add rally test gate.

To improve source stability, add a rally test case at the end of armada
deploy. The test lists run here are general-purpose tests that run on
multiple releases.

Change-Id: I91d81aa50b5e1e7b32ea84a45f9d7ac507cfeb3b

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 26201, 'date': '2017-09-29 04:55:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

[WIP] Opencontrail charts for openstack-helm

This PS adds opencontrail charts to openstack-helm repo. This is a work in
progress PS.

commit_message:
Add ansible apparmor role

This patch adds an ability to include new role 'deploy-apparmor', that would
setup apparmor package on Debian based OSes

Change-Id: Ieb5bb8ba9ddc894e13c59d2cfe6c16c262548940

commit_message:
build helm considering non-x86 platforms

Currently helm tools only consider x86 platform
This patch adds platform detection and installs related tools instead

'}, {'created': '2018-08-07 22:26:17.000000000', 'message': 'WIP:RabbitMQ-TLS: enable secure RabbitMQ transport

This patchset enable TLS ecncrypting for the interaction
between openstack services and RabbitMQ.

Signed-off-by: Ruslan Khanbikov <rk760n@att.com>

Change-Id: Ibc85e1fbd5922d5527d6f3b6714ed8b2c8108b16
Depends-On: Ia51a7df9458bd4fdd1aa2f55db3dc5a0a13b0736
'}, {'created': '2018-08-09 20:09:04.000000000', 'message': 'WIP:RabbitMQ-TLS: enable secure RabbitMQ transport

This patchset enable TLS ecncrypting for the interaction
between openstack services and RabbitMQ.

TLS certificates in transport_url:
oslo.messaging has hardcode which translate `rabbit://` or `kombu://`
to `amqp://` and no way to specify amqps wich librabbitmq(rabbitmq-c)
library requires, so that patch keeps using ssl parameters instead of
transport_url for tls certificates.

Signed-off-by: Ruslan Khanbikov <rk760n@att.com>

Change-Id: Ibc85e1fbd5922d5527d6f3b6714ed8b2c8108b16
Depends-On: Ia51a7df9458bd4fdd1aa2f55db3dc5a0a13b0736
'}, {'created': '2018-08-14 23:56:41.000000000', 'message': 'WIP:RabbitMQ-TLS: enable secure RabbitMQ transport

This patchset enables TLS ecncrypting for the interaction
between openstack services and RabbitMQ including management
ingerface and the client certificates verification and authentication.

Signed-off-by: Ruslan Khanbikov <rk760n@att.com>

Change-Id: Ibc85e1fbd5922d5527d6f3b6714ed8b2c8108b16
Depends-On: Ia51a7df9458bd4fdd1aa2f55db3dc5a0a13b0736

commit_message:
WIP:RabbitMQ-TLS: enable secure RabbitMQ transport

This patchset enables TLS ecncrypting for the interaction
between openstack services and RabbitMQ including management
ingerface and the client certificates verification and authentication.

Signed-off-by: Ruslan Khanbikov <rk760n@att.com>

Change-Id: Ibc85e1fbd5922d5527d6f3b6714ed8b2c8108b16
Depends-On: Ia51a7df9458bd4fdd1aa2f55db3dc5a0a13b0736

commit_message:
Add python-magnumclient package into LOCI image

Add python-magnumclient into LOCI image for magnum helm test.
OSC does not support magnum client in newton release, so
python-magnumclient is need for test as it in Kolla image.

Change-Id: If6dea55e22276af910840e0fdd5b9cee0d7e973e
Signed-off-by: Ranler Cao <caoran@fiberhome.com>

(9 comments)'}, {'account_id': 17591, 'date': '2018-07-25 21:28:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 13:

(2 comments)

I think we should also think about how we can include smarter alarms and alerts to supplement readiness and liveliness probes (ie: trigger an alarm for a service if we notice it's not functioning properly instead of just marking it unready or dead). I think that's the tie in with the LMA components provided in openstack-helm-infra. Can we highlight the possibility of introducing that here?"}, {'account_id': 22604, 'date': '2018-07-26 18:07:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13:

commit_message:
Spec for readiness and liveness probes

This patch set introduces a standard way to implement readiness
and liveness probes for all OpenStack-Helm charts.

Change-Id: I406b51241d8ac79ab4aed0b97b653fe4da13b548

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-08-07 22:18:00.000000000', 'message': 'WIP:RabbitMQ-TLS: enable secure communication

This patchset introduce TLS support for client/peer communication for
RabbitMQ and related htk defines for openstack helm charts.

TODO:
1. 644 file permission is set for certificates unless a way found
to get around inability to set uid/gid for secret files - TBD
2. restrict using tlsv1.2 - testing

Change-Id: Ia51a7df9458bd4fdd1aa2f55db3dc5a0a13b0736
Signed-off-by: Ruslan Khanbikov <rk760n@att.com>

commit_message:
WIP:RabbitMQ-TLS: enable secure communication

This patchset introduce
1) TLS support for client communication for RabbitMQ and
related htk defines for openstack helm charts.
2) High performance Erlang (HiPE) for RabbitMQ to increase throughput
by precompiling some modules. The startup time will be increased.
3) management plugin UI TLS
4) TLS support for inter-node comunication

TODO:
1. 644 file permission is set for certificates unless a way found
to get around inability to set uid/gid for secret files - TBD
3. 2 way TLS, client certificate verification - testing

Change-Id: Ia51a7df9458bd4fdd1aa2f55db3dc5a0a13b0736
Signed-off-by: Ruslan Khanbikov <rk760n@att.com>

commit_message:
Cinder: mount rootfs in read-only mode by default

The changes allow to mount root file system in read-only mode.
In some cases Cinder requires the mounting of an emptyDir volume.

Change-Id: I38e14ab41c8433ec17861fa023f1251800b8ce6f

an entrypoint init container.

commit_message:
Cinder: add pass message for enabling application

This PS add a pass message to prevent check message error.
These init sripts are failed because check message returned.
when using ceph (+luminous version) and a cinder pool already
has been enabled for other apps.

Change-Id: I79e8cc7176f2af60ae975ed38a9eb85c10b5c8aa
Closes-Bug: #1753535
