I don't see any direct use of novaclient directly in devstack and I would oppose it in the same way.

How about doing this special stuff in a glance devstack plugin like neutron does for sophisticated features? That would avoid the political discussion of OSC vs. glanceclient."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-06-23 19:29:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> How about doing this special stuff in a glance devstack plugin like
 > neutron does for sophisticated features? That would avoid the
 > political discussion of OSC vs. glanceclient.

Just to be clear, we want the cirros image that is uploaded during the main devstack phase to be import-converted like it would in a real deployment before it gets used by the tempest tests. So, yes, we could just do this completely out of band to make sure that the basic feature works, and I guess we could override tempest config to use the *other* image that we imported instead of the one devstack created, but that would be kind of silly and obscure for debugging no?

What is the motivation behind requiring everything in devstack to be done by OSC? Is it just the clouds.yaml support that is the sticking point? What devstack or infra requirement brings that forth?

I would maintain the position that devstack serves not to be a pinnacle of deployment purity, nor a motivator of cross-project goals, but a developer tool for testing openstack. Has devstack changed scope such that it has its own motivations for making projects do certain things independent of what the users of those projects need or the developers of those projects provide?'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2020-06-23 19:32:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-06-23 19:55:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2020-06-23 21:04:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Ok. After some discussion with some operators about preferences, I updated https://review.opendev.org/#/c/737608/ (adding tests this time) to continue to default to PUT - but to try import if we get a 403 from PUT (assuming that's a blocked-by-policy) - or if the user sets use_import=True. I've also added https://review.opendev.org/#/c/737608/ to expose an --import flag on the openstackclient command, which should allow more explicit use/testing like is desired in this patch.

It would be good to get confirmation that disabling by policy tosses a 403. Should we make a devstack config that disables upload_image by policy that can be used to verify that such a cloud still works with normal openstack image create commands?"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-06-23 21:22:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2020-06-24 05:53:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2020-06-24 06:33:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

(6 comments)

I'm a bit worried as most of the import code doesn't seem to get executed anywhere in the current jobs, so hidden errors would not get noticed."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-06-24 13:35:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2020-06-24 14:29:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-06-26 14:22:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-06-26 16:40:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

recheck dep changed mid test'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-07-07 13:34:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6: Patch Set 5 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2020-07-09 14:19:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

(2 comments)

I'm still uncomfortable with this because a lot of the different image variant aren't being tested in the normal CI jobs. Can we instead just modify what is needed for the nova job?"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-07-09 14:35:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

(2 comments)

> I'm still uncomfortable with this because a lot of the different
 > image variant aren't being tested in the normal CI jobs. Can we
 > instead just modify what is needed for the nova job?

The reason this is a bigger change than it needs to be is because the specific osc incantation for each are just copy/pasted everywhere, which is really messy, IMHO. If I were to make the minimal change, I'd still be touching each one of those osc calls, which wouldn't be tested, and just further propagating the lack of DRYness that makes this so ugly.

This is tested for the primary deployment types and works, and if the others test their cases once, then going forward we'll have a solid re-usable image upload function that will help avoid this concern in the future."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-07-09 14:54:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-07-13 18:06:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)

I am ok to get these bits in and start testing the import workflow. Best is to have glance run in uwsgi but as dan/abhshek mentioned those are big changes on glance side and we have been discussing those for years and did not happen for whatever reason. I cannot say only manpower is the reason for that but let's not get into those things again and let's the feature in existing way.

Waiting for the nova job result on latest results.
later we can add the nova-ceph-multistore job (once dan finish that) here (as n-v first) to have this tested on devstack gate too."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-07-13 18:15:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> I am ok to get these bits in and start testing the import workflow.
 > Best is to have glance run in uwsgi but as dan/abhshek mentioned
 > those are big changes on glance side and we have been discussing
 > those for years and did not happen for whatever reason. I cannot
 > say only manpower is the reason for that but let's not get into
 > those things again and let's the feature in existing way.

Just to be clear, I don't think the desire is to change glance to work better under uwsgi. The changes to make it work better under uwsgi would be large and involve substantial/fundamental changes to glance, which is why they have not happened. AFAIK, the community's move to uwsgi is not a goal shared by the glance team, and for understandable reasons.

Point being, I don't think changes to glance for more native uwsgi behavior are on the horizon any time soon, if ever, and not just for manpower reasons.

 > Waiting for the nova job result on latest results.
 > later we can add the nova-ceph-multistore job (once dan finish
 > that) here (as n-v first) to have this tested on devstack gate too.

FWIW, the changes in this patch only affect the early setup and import of the image, and not the tempest run, which has been failing for nova, glance and policy reasons lately. However, I think the latest run here will have all the stars aligned."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-07-13 18:37:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2020-07-13 20:56:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

LGTM, it's working now on nova patch, adding passing job log info in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/740322/"}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-07-15 10:07:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-06-16 16:34:07.000000000', 'message': "Use glance import workflow for crating image

Openstack client does not has support to use new glance import workflow,
which creates problem to use newly added import plugins like conversion,
inject metadata etc.

Added new boolean option 'GLANCE_USE_IMPORT_WORKFLOW' default to False.
If this parameter set in local.conf as True then devstack will use
new import workflow using python-glanceclient to create the image or
else will function as it is.

In order to use new import workflow of glance;
user need to set below options in local.conf

GLANCE_USE_IMPORT_WORKFLOW=True

Change-Id: I1306fe816b7a3eca1e2312c0c454be3d81118eca

Added new boolean option 'GLANCE_USE_IMPORT_WORKFLOW' default to False.
If this parameter set in local.conf as True then devstack will use the
new import workflow to create the image.

In order to use new import workflow of glance;
user need to set below options in local.conf

GLANCE_USE_IMPORT_WORKFLOW=True

Note that the import workflow requires WSGI_MODE=mod_wsgi, otherwise
glance will not be able to process the imports. The new helper function
will abort to avoid in that case to avoid waiting for something that
will never happen.

Co-Authored-By: Abhishek Kekane <akekane@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Dan Smith <dansmith@redhat.com>

In order to use new import workflow of glance;
user need to set below options in local.conf

GLANCE_USE_IMPORT_WORKFLOW=True

Note that the import workflow requires WSGI_MODE=mod_wsgi, otherwise
glance will not be able to process the imports. The new helper function
will abort to avoid in that case to avoid waiting for something that
will never happen.

commit_message:
Use glance import workflow for creating image

Added new boolean option 'GLANCE_USE_IMPORT_WORKFLOW' default to False.
If this parameter set in local.conf as True then devstack will use the
new import workflow to create the image.

In order to use new import workflow of glance;
user need to set below options in local.conf

GLANCE_USE_IMPORT_WORKFLOW=True

Note that the import workflow does not work in uwsgi because of
some fundamental restrictions it has. Thus, devstack must be configured
with WSGI_MODE=mod_wsgi, otherwise glance will not be able to process
the imports. The new helper function will abort to avoid in that case
to avoid the image never being moved to "active" state by an import
task that will never be executed.

Co-Authored-By: Abhishek Kekane <akekane@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Dan Smith <dansmith@redhat.com>
Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/734184
Change-Id: I1306fe816b7a3eca1e2312c0c454be3d81118eca

commit_message:
Add support for http_retries

The new http_retries option was added into neutron to define number of
retries in client connections.
This patch adds support for that new option.

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/736026/
Change-Id: Ifd7978c2404c6dd662d5e228bd7872cdfe00f4f4

commit_message:
hardware: refactor numa_get_constraints

Refactor numa_get_constraints to get all kinds of resource
constraints before creating numa cell instance.

These constraints will be used for calculating the 'dedicated'
CPU mask from 'PCPU' and 'VCPU' resource classes.

Change-Id: I5bc43f669a46f200794d2d9efb1488e8f5c70c80
Signed-off-by: Wang Huaqiang <huaqiang.wang@intel.com>

commit_message:
More helpful description for openstack/openstack

The openstack/openstack repository is often mistaken as being the
default entry point into the OpenStack world. In addition to
providing redirects in its README[1], update the repo description
to make it clearer what it actually is.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/741207

Change-Id: Ib3832589cf05ff7c5063e0c2c26dfe0ef342c700

[{'created': '2020-06-26 09:59:45.000000000', 'message': 'L3 agent scheduler should return a valid index if manual scheduling

When retrieving a vacant L3 agent binding index, if
"is_manual_scheduling" is set, the method "get_vacant_binding_index"
should always return a valid binding index. If the existing binding
indexes are sequentially aligned, the method will return a new one
on top; if there is a gap in the binding indexes list, the first
free index will be returned.

Closes-Bug: #1884906

Change-Id: I0a89bca0734d3e735fb357e488f85589e81d709f
(cherry picked from commit 2bb514f2d73a64b6f954990a2ff12f5baa3a97cd)
'}]
commit_message:
L3 agent scheduler should return a valid index if manual scheduling

When retrieving a vacant L3 agent binding index, if
"is_manual_scheduling" is set, the method "get_vacant_binding_index"
should always return a valid binding index. If the existing binding
indexes are sequentially aligned, the method will return a new one
on top; if there is a gap in the binding indexes list, the first
free index will be returned.

Closes-Bug: #1884906

Change-Id: I0a89bca0734d3e735fb357e488f85589e81d709f
(cherry picked from commit 2bb514f2d73a64b6f954990a2ff12f5baa3a97cd)

commit_message:
Refresh cipher suites and protocols

The last update was 2016, and it's time to drop TLSv1 and TLSv1.1 as the
base configuration recommended by Mozilla.
https://wiki.mozilla.org/Security/Server_Side_TLS

Follow-up of the following commits:
106f418f13c073b1e7d4c57483f423d5f4d0dd10

Related changes in charm-helpers:
https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/485

Change-Id: Ib959663634bc648328e5cb35ed3d3622d759412c
Closes-Bug: #1886630

commit_message:
Fix pep8 job

New versions of isort broke pylint. This patch fixes it at 4.3.21.

Set PYTHON3_VERSION to 3, to avoid errors with pip3.6 not found

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/739469
Change-Id: I2c71fecdaa194a343f4f360d9c7e09830d814b4a

due to transition to Python3 and the absence of this package in

commit_message:
Removing libselinux-python package from Fedora dependencies

In the past releasaes of Fedora, bifrost setup had a dependency on
libselinux-python package. In Fedora 32 this package no longer exists
due to transition to Python3 and the absence of this package in
Fedora 32 repos this causes the playbook to fail.

This change removes libselinux-python from Bifrost Fedora dependencies
and resolves the issue.

Change-Id: Id767e76bb0afb91f4176fd02ad1fa33f17325df2
(cherry picked from commit f4f456d38770ca9f048d426cf8c6921fc77415ef)

commit_message:
Fix Logstash 2.4 log rotation

Logstash 2.4 uses integrated in container logrotate configuration
which tries to rotate logs in /var/log/logstash and Kolla's Logstash
logs are in /var/log/kolla/logstash/
This patch adds kolla-ansible internal logrotate config for Logstash

Change-Id: Ifbab7b673ba87925e52bb01c0996479eb1b76c44
Closes-Bug: #1886787

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-15 13:50:29.000000000', 'message': 'Give general OpenStack info in the README

Some newcomers sometimes browse gitea or GitHub to learn about
OpenStack and naturally open the openstack/openstack repository,
only to find a confusing and pretty technical explanation about
submodule tracking and the subtleties of tested combinations of
components.

Provide some general information about OpenStack first, to
redirect those lose souls to friendler shores.

Change-Id: I41cde655f6c5d08fc482c40953687570acd59d3f
'}]
commit_message:
Give general OpenStack info in the README

Some newcomers sometimes browse gitea or GitHub to learn about
OpenStack and naturally open the openstack/openstack repository,
only to find a confusing and pretty technical explanation about
submodule tracking and the subtleties of tested combinations of
components.

Provide some general information about OpenStack first, to
redirect those lose souls to friendler shores.

commit_message:
[OVN] Don't set virtual port type on ports with similar addresses

Because of broken check why one port has similar address to the other
one, the first one by mistake could be set as virtual.
Example:
 port_1: 10.11.1.100
 port_2: 10.11.1.10

On create of port_2 it is set as 'virtual', but shouldn't.

This patch fixes that bug by using common function
utils.get_ovn_port_addresses().

Cherry-picked from Neutron: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/732690/

Change-Id: Ia4b986146c77edf0616015380359e37233df80fc
Closes-Bug: #1881759
(cherry picked from commit e6023ecb482ee0dc7e29739b94e009c275cc24a1)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-29 17:20:55.000000000', 'message': "Set class ovsdb_conection to None

We override ovsdbapp's Backend class to change from using a class
variable for the ovsdb_connection to using an instance variable.
This means we have to override several different methods/properties.
This could be simplified in ovsdbapp by making ovsdb_connection a
property, which in ovsdbapp access a class variable, and in neutron
it is overridden to to store on the instance, so there would be
less to override.

ovsdbapp is adding user-definable indexed columns so things like
lookups by name will be faster. Due to the way it is architected,
the place to generate the indexes would be just before the
connection starts. Since methods like start_connection are
classmethods in ovsdbapp, and instance methods in neutron, this is
hard to do cleanly w/o ovsdb_connection being a property. Without
this change, neutron would fail if that property was defined. With
the change, it should pass with both old and new code.

Change-Id: Idd184807de24c79dd892046f01e3acdd1168ca2d
(cherry picked from commit c05bac8c4062ff2d4bb67a719aa11f61f608bbdb)
"}, {'created': '2020-07-15 08:35:25.000000000', 'message': "Set class ovsdb_conection to None

hard to do cleanly w/o ovsdb_connection being a property. Without
this change, neutron would fail if that property was defined. With
the change, it should pass with both old and new code.

Change-Id: Idd184807de24c79dd892046f01e3acdd1168ca2d
(cherry picked from commit c05bac8c4062ff2d4bb67a719aa11f61f608bbdb)
"}]
commit_message:
Set class ovsdb_conection to None

We override ovsdbapp's Backend class to change from using a class
variable for the ovsdb_connection to using an instance variable.
This means we have to override several different methods/properties.
This could be simplified in ovsdbapp by making ovsdb_connection a
property, which in ovsdbapp access a class variable, and in neutron
it is overridden to to store on the instance, so there would be
less to override.

ovsdbapp is adding user-definable indexed columns so things like
lookups by name will be faster. Due to the way it is architected,
the place to generate the indexes would be just before the
connection starts. Since methods like start_connection are
classmethods in ovsdbapp, and instance methods in neutron, this is
hard to do cleanly w/o ovsdb_connection being a property. Without
this change, neutron would fail if that property was defined. With
the change, it should pass with both old and new code.

Change-Id: Idd184807de24c79dd892046f01e3acdd1168ca2d
(cherry picked from commit c05bac8c4062ff2d4bb67a719aa11f61f608bbdb)

commit_message:
Set class ovsdb_conection to None

We override ovsdbapp's Backend class to change from using a class
variable for the ovsdb_connection to using an instance variable.
This means we have to override several different methods/properties.
This could be simplified in ovsdbapp by making ovsdb_connection a
property, which in ovsdbapp access a class variable, and in neutron
it is overridden to to store on the instance, so there would be
less to override.

ovsdbapp is adding user-definable indexed columns so things like
lookups by name will be faster. Due to the way it is architected,
the place to generate the indexes would be just before the
connection starts. Since methods like start_connection are
classmethods in ovsdbapp, and instance methods in neutron, this is
hard to do cleanly w/o ovsdb_connection being a property. Without
this change, neutron would fail if that property was defined. With
the change, it should pass with both old and new code.

Change-Id: Idd184807de24c79dd892046f01e3acdd1168ca2d
(cherry picked from commit c05bac8c4062ff2d4bb67a719aa11f61f608bbdb)

We override ovsdbapp's Backend class to change from using a class
variable for the ovsdb_connection to using an instance variable.
This means we have to override several different methods/properties.
This could be simplified in ovsdbapp by making ovsdb_connection a

ovsdbapp is adding user-definable indexed columns so things like

commit_message:
Fix OVN Octavia provider driver package name

In Ussuri cycle, the OVN Octavia provider driver moved out
of the networking-ovn RPM to its own RPM.

Change-Id: I19b1dda0d10765651ad61682d0783f9253873063
(cherry picked from commit 3c8f2144854284ee891759cb40511e2e043ef526)

commit_message:
tcib/ceilometer-base: remove panko dependency

Aodh was deprecated, panko isn't needed anymore for ceilometer images.
We already didn't ship it on OSP, let's align with the upstream image.

Change-Id: I5f08cd74b19362611c76ecf31befd3b7eaf5a010
(cherry picked from commit ab65e221b4b2a7d5d16be72bcb1fcb434e6864d9)

[{'created': '2020-07-03 09:22:29.000000000', 'message': 'Manila - adjust logic for Open vSwitch configuration generation

Work was done to selectively enable Open vSwitch deployment for Manila
services as bug #1884939.  However this did not appear to catch all
cases.  This patch adds a couple more.

Change-Id: I6187997a00f908e87ceace6f79f5f7262ea78738
Closes-Bug: #1886166
Co-Authored-By: Sebastian Luna Valero <sebastian.luna.valero@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Manila - adjust logic for Open vSwitch configuration generation

Work was done to selectively enable Open vSwitch deployment for Manila
services as bug #1884939.  However this did not appear to catch all
cases.  This patch adds a couple more.

Change-Id: I6187997a00f908e87ceace6f79f5f7262ea78738
Closes-Bug: #1886166
Co-Authored-By: Sebastian Luna Valero <sebastian.luna.valero@gmail.com>

Although looks like that isn't working on 2.4 since the logs go to /var/log/kolla.."}, {'account_id': 23084, 'date': '2020-07-09 10:37:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Logstash 6 uses log4j2 and its own log rotation/compression mechanism. However, by default Logstash 6 is not deleting old rotated/compressed logs -https://github.com/elastic/logstash/issues/11883 
https://github.com/elastic/elasticsearch/blob/6.8/distribution/src/config/log4j2.properties

this will be fixed at container build level in next patch'}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2020-07-09 10:58:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

I'm happy with patching the built in log rotation in the Kolla image to remove logs. We have avoided the Kolla mechanism because it's simpler to use the built in mechanism rather than go to the effort of disabling it (it should work out of the box in ELK7) and there are some concerns about losing logs with the Kolla mechanism."}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2020-07-10 10:55:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)

Inline comments are nits.

I could only trust that this works. subject: Stop adding entry in local_user while updating ephemerals
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 8482, 'name': 'Colleen Murphy', 'email': 'colleen@gazlene.net', 'username': 'krinkle'}, {'_account_id': 15054, 'name': 'wangxiyuan', 'email': 'wangxiyuan1007@gmail.com', 'username': 'wangxiyuan'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 27621, 'name': 'Vishakha Agarwal', 'email': 'agarwalvishakha18@gmail.com', 'username': 'Vishakha'}, {'_account_id': 28356, 'name': 'Rafael Weingartner', 'email': 'rafael@apache.org', 'username': 'rafaelweingartner'}, {'_account_id': 30695, 'name': 'Pedro Henrique Pereira Martins', 'email': 'phpm13@gmail.com', 'username': 'pedrohpmartins'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 30695, 'date': '2019-10-10 21:54:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-10-10 22:53:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

It looks like a reasonable change. Currently, this is kind of a bug, when we use the update command in OpenStack CLI, federated users are written to the local_users table.'}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2019-10-11 07:03:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Hi Pedro. In k2k federation, when the federated user tries to access the SP keystone a shadow user is being created in the local user table so that the federated user can be given some access over the SP keystone. You can read more about the shadow user [1]

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/keystone-specs/specs/keystone/mitaka/shadow-users.html;

AFAIK this error isn't coming due to the entry in local user. Please register a bug with all the logs and tables so that we can look for the problem."}, {'account_id': 30695, 'date': '2019-10-11 12:08:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 30695, 'date': '2019-10-11 14:18:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 30695, 'date': '2019-10-11 19:29:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 30695, 'date': '2019-10-11 19:34:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Hi Pedro. In k2k federation, when the federated user tries to
 > access the SP keystone a shadow user is being created in the local
 > user table so that the federated user can be given some access over
 > the SP keystone. You can read more about the shadow user [1]
 > 
 > [1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/keystone-specs/specs/keystone/mitaka/shadow-users.html;
 > 
 > AFAIK this error isn't coming due to the entry in local user.
 > Please register a bug with all the logs and tables so that we can
 > look for the problem.

Hi Vishakha, I agree with your concerns and changed the proposal, can you take another look?"}, {'account_id': 30695, 'date': '2019-10-13 00:20:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-10-13 19:06:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-10-14 22:21:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

I am unable to recreate the problem described. Could you create a bug report and include examples of the output you are seeing from curl, the entries in the local_user and federated_user tables, your mapping rules, and any relevant logs? https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+filebug

Does your mapping use the "local" user type or the "ephemeral" user type? When I try this using the "local" type, the federated user is never entered into the federated_user table and only the local_user is used. When I try with the "ephemeral" type, it only appears in the federated_user table.

What version of keystone are you using?'}, {'account_id': 30695, 'date': '2019-10-16 13:26:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 30695, 'date': '2019-10-16 13:29:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> I am unable to recreate the problem described. Could you create a
 > bug report and include examples of the output you are seeing from
 > curl, the entries in the local_user and federated_user tables, your
 > mapping rules, and any relevant logs? https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+filebug
 > 
 > Does your mapping use the "local" user type or the "ephemeral" user
 > type? When I try this using the "local" type, the federated user is
 > never entered into the federated_user table and only the local_user
 > is used. When I try with the "ephemeral" type, it only appears in
 > the federated_user table.
 > 
 > What version of keystone are you using?


Hello Colleen, the version of keystone is the 14.0.1 (Rocky),
here is the link to the issue: https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/1848342

Thanks for the review'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-10-16 20:46:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

Thanks for the bug report, I now agree this is a bug but filtering isn't the right approach, see my comment in the bug report."}, {'account_id': 30695, 'date': '2019-10-17 21:36:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 30695, 'date': '2019-10-18 02:01:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-10-18 10:29:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 30695, 'date': '2019-10-18 12:30:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> Thanks for the bug report, I now agree this is a bug but filtering
 > isn't the right approach, see my comment in the bug report.

Hi Colleen, I did some changes in the approach, could you take a look?"}, {'account_id': 30695, 'date': '2019-10-22 19:46:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 30695, 'date': '2019-10-28 14:30:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 30695, 'date': '2019-10-28 17:51:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 30695, 'date': '2019-10-28 21:49:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 30695, 'date': '2019-10-29 00:15:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Hi guys, everything looks good to be merged. Would you guys mind to review it? Do I need to change something else?'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-10-31 18:39:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 30695, 'date': '2019-11-21 19:09:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Hi folks, could someone check this PR? Do I need to change something else?'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-12-01 22:06:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

This approach is too broad. The problem is not that the user-facing API allows updating federated users, it's simply a bug in the implementation of the shadow_federated_user method (which purposefully does a user update to ensure the shadow users attributes are in sync with the IdP) and/or the underlying sqlalchemy driver code which is wrongly creating a record in the local_user table."}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-12-02 01:01:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

> This approach is too broad. The problem is not that the user-facing
 > API allows updating federated users, it's simply a bug in the
 > implementation of the shadow_federated_user method (which
 > purposefully does a user update to ensure the shadow users
 > attributes are in sync with the IdP) and/or the underlying
 > sqlalchemy driver code which is wrongly creating a record in the
 > local_user table.

Colleen Murphy, can you be more specific/clear? Your comment looks very similar to what you said in (a long time ago) https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/1848342. However, if you take a look into the code, we are not just blocking the update from the user side in the API. The proposal here is actually fixing the update of the shadow_federated_user, which was the solution we seemed to have discussed already. Can you provide a more clear feedback on what you dislike here in this solution?"}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-12-02 02:18:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

> > This approach is too broad. The problem is not that the
 > user-facing
 > > API allows updating federated users, it's simply a bug in the
 > > implementation of the shadow_federated_user method (which
 > > purposefully does a user update to ensure the shadow users
 > > attributes are in sync with the IdP) and/or the underlying
 > > sqlalchemy driver code which is wrongly creating a record in the
 > > local_user table.
 > 
 > Colleen Murphy, can you be more specific/clear? Your comment looks
 > very similar to what you said in (a long time ago)
 > https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/1848342. However, if you
 > take a look into the code, we are not just blocking the update from
 > the user side in the API. The proposal here is actually fixing the
 > update of the shadow_federated_user, which was the solution we
 > seemed to have discussed already. Can you provide a more clear
 > feedback on what you dislike here in this solution?

The change that introduced this bug is here: https://review.opendev.org/549723

The change was made for good reason, email is a valid attribute in the shadow user mapping, and so we don't want to block updating it. Changing the PATCH API for /v3/users to disallow it would also be an API-breaking change which we need to avoid.

My suggestion is not to change the patch method in keystone/api/users.py, but instead to just change either shadow_federated_user in keystone/identity/core.py to avoid using update_user which seems to be doing the wrong thing, or fix the SQL driver's update_user method to ensure it doesn't touch the local_user table but only touches the user table."}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-12-04 12:43:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: -Code-Review

> > > This approach is too broad. The problem is not that the
 > > user-facing
 > > > API allows updating federated users, it's simply a bug in the
 > > > implementation of the shadow_federated_user method (which
 > > > purposefully does a user update to ensure the shadow users
 > > > attributes are in sync with the IdP) and/or the underlying
 > > > sqlalchemy driver code which is wrongly creating a record in
 > the
 > > > local_user table.
 > >
 > > Colleen Murphy, can you be more specific/clear? Your comment
 > looks
 > > very similar to what you said in (a long time ago)
 > > https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/1848342. However, if you
 > > take a look into the code, we are not just blocking the update
 > from
 > > the user side in the API. The proposal here is actually fixing
 > the
 > > update of the shadow_federated_user, which was the solution we
 > > seemed to have discussed already. Can you provide a more clear
 > > feedback on what you dislike here in this solution?
 > 
 > The change that introduced this bug is here: https://review.opendev.org/549723
 > 
 > The change was made for good reason, email is a valid attribute in
 > the shadow user mapping, and so we don't want to block updating it.
 > Changing the PATCH API for /v3/users to disallow it would also be
 > an API-breaking change which we need to avoid.
 > 
 > My suggestion is not to change the patch method in
 > keystone/api/users.py, but instead to just change either
 > shadow_federated_user in keystone/identity/core.py to avoid using
 > update_user which seems to be doing the wrong thing, or fix the SQL
 > driver's update_user method to ensure it doesn't touch the
 > local_user table but only touches the user table.

That is the point, I do understand that the first proposal was to simply block the ability to update the value from the API. However, if you look into the changes now, Pedro is actually fixing the update process as you suggested.

Moreover, Pedro fixed the inconsistency with the getter and setter of the name property that was generating the bug, and the setter of the password property (federated users should not have password in OpenStack). Then, we blocked federated users (true federated users, do not confuse with the local users that are authenticating in the IdP) to update attributes directly in OpenStack, they should instead execute the update in the IdP, and then during the login process the updated attributes are gathered and updated by Keystone."}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-12-04 17:42:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

> > > > This approach is too broad. The problem is not that the
 > > > user-facing
 > > > > API allows updating federated users, it's simply a bug in the

 > > > > attributes are in sync with the IdP) and/or the underlying
 > > > > sqlalchemy driver code which is wrongly creating a record in
 > > the

 > > > Colleen Murphy, can you be more specific/clear? Your comment
 > > looks
 > > > very similar to what you said in (a long time ago)
 > > > https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/1848342. However, if
 > you
 > > > take a look into the code, we are not just blocking the update

 > >

 > in

 > it.
 > > Changing the PATCH API for /v3/users to disallow it would also be

The current proposal blocks the update from the API: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/687990/9/keystone/api/users.py

 > 
 > Moreover, Pedro fixed the inconsistency with the getter and setter
 > of the name property that was generating the bug, and the setter of
 > the password property (federated users should not have password in
 > OpenStack). Then, we blocked federated users (true federated users,

 > IdP) to update attributes directly in OpenStack, they should

 > process the updated attributes are gathered and updated by

None of that is part of the bug. The bug is the duplicated entry due to the extra shadowed user that happens when the user logs in, not when the user's password is changed or anything else about the user is changed by the administrator."}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-12-04 17:49:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

 > > > > > purposefully does a user update to ensure the shadow users

 > > > > > sqlalchemy driver code which is wrongly creating a record
 > in
 > > > the
 > > > > > local_user table.
 > > > >
 > > > > Colleen Murphy, can you be more specific/clear? Your comment
 > > > looks
 > > > > very similar to what you said in (a long time ago)

 > > you

 > > > from

 > > >

 > > in

 > > it.

I think I am not expressing myself properly. The user is being created in the local user table because of that "name" setter there (did you see the changes?). It was not properly coded before. Can you please get the PR and test it yourself? Then, you will see that it fix the reported problem.

Now, with respect of blocking attribute updates, that was only to make the solution comprehensive. Federated users (the true federated users) should not have their attributed updated in OpenStack, but rather in the IdP. However, if that it the only reason for you to block this fix, we can have that validation, and allow attributes to be updated for federated users as well. This can create quite a good mess though, and that is why we proposed to fix this as well.'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2019-12-04 19:32:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-10 21:54:07.000000000', 'message': 'Validate federated users when updating attributes.

Problem description
===================
Today we have a consistency problem when updating federated
users via OpenStack. When I update a federated user via OpenStack,
a registry in the local_user table is created, making this user
having entries in user, local_user and federated_user tables in
the database.

Furthermore, if I try to do some operations using this user
(that has entries in all three tables), I get a "More than one
user exists with the name ..." error from the OpenStack
Keystone API. It happens because the user has an entry in both
local_user and federated_user tables.

To fix the persistence in the local_user table for federated
users when doing updates is not ideal. I think that the update
for federated user's attributes must not be allowed via
OpenStack.In a federated environment, the responsibility for
managing the user attributes must be delegated to the Identity
Provider. Therefore, there is no reason to allow updating
federated users' attributes directly via OpenStack as if they
were local users. If users need to change something in their
attributes, they must do that in the Identity Provider.
If some admin desires to change some federated user's
attribute, then he/she needs to ask for the user to change that
in the Idp or request the Idp to do that for her/him. It is the
responsibility of the Identity Provider to maintain the
federated user's attributes updated, not OpenStack's.

Proposal
========
I propose to validate users while updating users' attributes;
if the user is federated, then we throw an error, otherwise,
maintain the current behavior (which means, allowing the
update of local users data).

Change-Id: I2ac6e90f24b94dc5c0d9c0758f008a388597036c
'}, {'created': '2019-10-11 12:08:37.000000000', 'message': 'Validate federated users when updating attributes.

Problem description
===================
Today we have a consistency problem when updating federated
users via OpenStack. When I update a federated user via OpenStack,
a registry in the local_user table is created, making this user
having entries in user, local_user and federated_user tables in
the database.

Furthermore, if I try to do some operations using this user
(that has entries in all three tables), I get a "More than one
user exists with the name ..." error from the OpenStack
Keystone API. It happens because the user has an entry in both
local_user and federated_user tables.

To fix the persistence in the local_user table for federated
users when doing updates is not ideal. I think that the update
for federated user's attributes must not be allowed via
OpenStack.In a federated environment, the responsibility for
managing the user attributes must be delegated to the Identity
Provider. Therefore, there is no reason to allow updating
federated users' attributes directly via OpenStack as if they
were local users. If users need to change something in their
attributes, they must do that in the Identity Provider.
If some admin desires to change some federated user's
attribute, then he/she needs to ask for the user to change that
in the Idp or request the Idp to do that for her/him. It is the
responsibility of the Identity Provider to maintain the
federated user's attributes updated, not OpenStack's.

Proposal
========
I propose to validate users while updating users' attributes;
if the user is federated, then we throw an error, otherwise,
maintain the current behavior (which means, allowing the
update of local users data).

Change-Id: I2ac6e90f24b94dc5c0d9c0758f008a388597036c
'}, {'created': '2019-10-11 19:29:03.000000000', 'message': 'Remove duplicated entries from users API

Problem description
===================
When I use the Keystone `users` API, if I add the filter `name`
in the request, and the name passed in the request is from a
federated user, I get duplicated entries for the same users, one
that comes from the local_user table and another from
federated_user, both with the same user_id and data.

Proposal
========
I propose to filter duplicated users by id from the shadow_user
handler returned list.

Change-Id: I2ac6e90f24b94dc5c0d9c0758f008a388597036c
'}, {'created': '2019-10-13 00:20:14.000000000', 'message': 'Remove duplicated entries from users API

Problem description
===================
When I use the Keystone `users` API, if I add the filter `name`
in the request, and the name passed in the request is from a
federated user, I get duplicated entries for the same users, one
that comes from the local_user table and another from
federated_user, both with the same user_id and data.

Proposal
========
I propose to filter duplicated users by id from the shadow_user
handler returned list.

Change-Id: I2ac6e90f24b94dc5c0d9c0758f008a388597036c
'}, {'created': '2019-10-16 13:26:59.000000000', 'message': 'Remove duplicated entries from users API

Problem description
===================
When I use the Keystone `users` API, if I add the filter `name`
in the request, and the name passed in the request is from a
federated user, I get duplicated entries for the same users, one
that comes from the local_user table and another from
federated_user, both with the same user_id and data.

Proposal
========
I propose to filter duplicated users by id from the shadow_user
handler returned list.

Closes-Bug: #1848342

Change-Id: I2ac6e90f24b94dc5c0d9c0758f008a388597036c
'}, {'created': '2019-10-17 21:36:04.000000000', 'message': 'Stop adding entry in local_user while updating ephemerals

Problem description
===================
Today we have a consistency problem when updating federated
users via OpenStack. When I update a ephemeral user via OpenStack,
a registry in the local_user table is created, making this user
having entries in user, local_user and federated_user tables in
the database.

Furthermore, if I try to do some operations using this user
(that has entries in all three tables), I get a "More than one
user exists with the name ..." error from the OpenStack
Keystone API. It happens because the user has an entry in both
local_user and federated_user tables.

I fix the persistence in the local_user table for ephemeral
users when doing updates. Also, I think that the update
for ephemeral user's attributes must not be allowed via
OpenStack.In a federated environment, the responsibility for
managing the user attributes must be delegated to the Identity
Provider. Therefore, there is no reason to allow updating
ephemeral users' attributes directly via OpenStack as if they
were local users. If users need to change something in their
attributes, they must do that in the Identity Provider.
If some admin desires to change some ephemeral user's
attribute, then he/she needs to ask for the user to change that
in the Idp or request the Idp to do that for her/him. It is the
responsibility of the Identity Provider to maintain the
federated user's attributes updated, not OpenStack's.

Proposal
========
I propose to validate users while updating users' attributes;
if the user is ephemeral, then we throw an error, otherwise,
maintain the current behavior (which means, allowing the
update of local users data).

Also I fix the problem with creating an entry in the
local_user table while updating an ephemeral user

Closes-Bug: #1848342

Change-Id: I2ac6e90f24b94dc5c0d9c0758f008a388597036c

commit_message:
Stop adding entry in local_user while updating ephemerals

Problem description
===================
Today we have a consistency problem when updating federated
users via OpenStack. When I update a ephemeral user via OpenStack,
a registry in the local_user table is created, making this user
having entries in user, local_user and federated_user tables in
the database.

Furthermore, if I try to do some operations using this user
(that has entries in all three tables), I get a "More than one
user exists with the name ..." error from the OpenStack
Keystone API. It happens because the user has an entry in both
local_user and federated_user tables.

I fix the persistence in the local_user table for ephemeral
users when doing updates.

Proposal
========
I fix the problem with creating an entry in the
local_user table while updating an ephemeral user

Closes-Bug: #1848342

Change-Id: I2ac6e90f24b94dc5c0d9c0758f008a388597036c

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-29 01:51:50.000000000', 'message': "Allow scale-down of ASG as part of update

When user wants to do manual scale-up of ASG by increasing the
desired_capacity and also update some member properties as
part of a stack update, if it fails due to insufficient
resources when resizing, trying to manually scale-down by
decreasing the desired_capacity won't work, as it would
always expect to update the group with the earlier size
before scaling down.

This patch uses the target_size when building the batches.

Task: 39867
Change-Id: Id851530b424f68b5e0e967fe34431483bfffd852
(cherry picked from commit 26d8f64fc90ed9b3ad0413ed0c932fb91b51d666)
"}]
commit_message:
Allow scale-down of ASG as part of update

When user wants to do manual scale-up of ASG by increasing the
desired_capacity and also update some member properties as
part of a stack update, if it fails due to insufficient
resources when resizing, trying to manually scale-down by
decreasing the desired_capacity won't work, as it would
always expect to update the group with the earlier size
before scaling down.

This patch uses the target_size when building the batches.

Task: 39867
Change-Id: Id851530b424f68b5e0e967fe34431483bfffd852
(cherry picked from commit 26d8f64fc90ed9b3ad0413ed0c932fb91b51d666)

commit_message:
Always reset CONF when starting the wsgi app

This ensures that options loaded during any prior run of the
application are dropped before being added again during init_application.

Change-Id: I599b4b301d1eb8c5824f378dfd7fdcf8145d11aa

commit_message:
Do not clone repos with source_install==false

Switch ironic-staging-drivers to source installation since
it's released very infrequently.

Do not clone keystone if it's not enabled

Change-Id: If01ae7c54d5d421a5c6b97a4d8b29bdaa722ddd9

[{'created': '2020-07-12 19:28:03.000000000', 'message': 'add property methods to extension for more entry point values

The underlying EntryPoint class has some similar methods to fetch
these values, but they depend on the version of importlib.metadata
that is installed, so this provides a consistent API

commit_message:
add property methods to extension for more entry point values

The underlying EntryPoint class has some similar methods to fetch
these values, but they depend on the version of importlib.metadata
that is installed, so this provides a consistent API

Change-Id: I7a1b9541f0e4042a224e49c890ba3c63e8a5a259
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Add support for the interface parameter in authtoken middleware

This patch adds support for [keystone_authtoken] interface parameter,
so that operators can define which endpoint should be used by authtoken
middleware.

Change-Id: I494c1e25c98a57b78c779bcd0bf30c92fe70ff0a

commit_message:
Removing libselinux-python package from Fedora dependencies

In the past releasaes of Fedora, bifrost setup had a dependency on
libselinux-python package. In Fedora 32 this package no longer exists
due to transition to Python3 and the absence of this package in
Fedora 32 repos this causes the playbook to fail.

This change removes libselinux-python from Bifrost Fedora dependencies
and resolves the issue.

Change-Id: Id767e76bb0afb91f4176fd02ad1fa33f17325df2

[{'created': '2020-07-10 13:45:17.000000000', 'message': 'Use min_command_interval when ironic does IPMI retries

For certain BMCs the default of 1 second is too short for the ipmitool
minimum command interval (-N).  The configured
``[ipmi]min_command_interval`` should be used.

Story: 2007914
Task: 40317

Change-Id: I07f17a7321582e9829ac422efb51b571a17c5ca8

commit_message:
Use min_command_interval when ironic does IPMI retries

For certain BMCs the default of 1 second is too short for the ipmitool
minimum command interval (-N).  The configured
``[ipmi]min_command_interval`` should be used.

Story: 2007914
Task: 40317

Change-Id: I07f17a7321582e9829ac422efb51b571a17c5ca8

commit_message:
add buildah to overcloud-base

buildah is required on the overcloud for deployment.  In the case
that yum repos are not enabled during the deployment this change is
required.

Change-Id: I24acd6d3fe2f4b113eb3391b7c7d1def942a87cd

commit_message:
Add to_dict and from_dict conversions to managed objects

This patch centralizes the managed objects conversion in order to be
used across multiple key_manager backends.

Change-Id: Ia2e15d46eb2e504b815a7f51173aecaf82978402

commit_message:
Add support for the interface parameter in authtoken middleware

This patch adds support for [keystone_authtoken] interface parameter,
so that operators can define which endpoint should be used by authtoken
middleware.

Change-Id: I2dad56c1d3fdeca153df9a18c7ef4174b3a20848

commit_message:
Added OctaviaDeploymentConfig to deployed server role

The Octavia ansible deployment tasks are missing from deployed server
role. This is only relevant for stein and older branches.

Change-Id: I671b770304345d780de4720b5693c1b9991f1ef8
Closes-Bug: #1864915
(cherry picked from commit 38af103fc563a71eaeabc03793d218c11ddb57a2)

commit_message:
Add focal and ussuri test bundles to the charm

Note: this will fail due to Bug: #1865754 which affects os-brick and
Ceph Octopus in focal.  This can be landed or the focal-ussuri bundle
disabled to a dev bundle whilst waiting on the fix.

Change-Id: I45ef775ad177e52b2ac6eaccd196c9518d25c03c
Closes-Bug: #1879684
Related-Bug: #1865754

commit_message:
Unstable test_server_connectivity_cold_migration_revert

The bug which was the reason for skipping the bug has got expired
which suggests that the test is no longer causing problems.
Just to make sure the test works, let's mark the test as unstable
for a while.

Change-Id: I4c68caa693744e06de6be89a8f09d8f7e8ce8ba0
Related-Bug: #1836595

The Reference section has an incorrect link for Mistral Client/CLI Guide, as per page link is https://docs.openstack.org/mistral/latest/install/mistralclient_guide.html whereas the correct link is https://docs.openstack.org/mistral/latest/admin/install/mistralclient_guide.html . '}, {'created': '2020-07-13 08:36:23.000000000', 'message': 'Fix for broken link

for Tacker page. The Reference section has an incorrect link for
Mistral Client/CLI Guide, as per page link is [1] whereas the
correct link is [2].
[1] https://docs.openstack.org/mistral/latest/install/mistralclient_guide.html
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/mistral/latest/admin/install/mistralclient_guide.html

Closes-Bug: #1880545
Change-Id: Ifa5a203f3b8c67bf6a4807d5988876d586cb3951
'}]
commit_message:
Fix for broken link

Tacker Installation Guide has an incorrect link in Mistral workflows
for Tacker page. The Reference section has an incorrect link for
Mistral Client/CLI Guide, as per page link is [1] whereas the
correct link is [2].
[1] https://docs.openstack.org/mistral/latest/install/mistralclient_guide.html
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/mistral/latest/admin/install/mistralclient_guide.html

Closes-Bug: #1880545
Change-Id: Ifa5a203f3b8c67bf6a4807d5988876d586cb3951

commit_message:
Don't use pacemaker in ironic sa job

- Stop using Pacemaker in Ironic Standalone job
- Remove Docker resource (and use Podman)
- Add missing EndpointMap to ci/common/ironic_standalone_post.yaml

Change-Id: Ie86e20c8a2219c3b96da9abdc35bf13cb539fce9

[{'created': '2020-06-28 09:55:07.000000000', 'message': 'CI: Install python deps, mark oraclelinux rsyslog as skipped

setuptools is missing from infra image - so it needs to be installed.

Copy cat of a kolla-ansible change: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/735808/

Disables rsyslog build on oraclelinux (both source and binary) and
tripleoclient (binary).

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/738343
Change-Id: I6068abcbc0e73eeab77b0aa99983a95adc6defd3
(cherry picked from commit d12137ce64fab7e8436aa1c2e32e3bc6ed47c1a1)

Disables rsyslog build on oraclelinux (both source and binary) and
tripleoclient (binary).

Stops installing ansible (this is the build part, kolla-ansible has its
own repo and jobs).

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/738343
Change-Id: I6068abcbc0e73eeab77b0aa99983a95adc6defd3
(cherry picked from commit d12137ce64fab7e8436aa1c2e32e3bc6ed47c1a1)
'}, {'created': '2020-06-29 11:27:10.000000000', 'message': 'Fix multiple issues

1. Fix monasca-grafana by pinning more Ruby gems

childprocess 3.0.0 and ffi 1.13.0 depend on Ruby 2.3.

2. Bump bifrost to 6.0.4

Bifrost had a fix to stop using the master branch of DIB which dropped
support for Python 2.

3. Drop docker-client from OracleLinux sensu-client image

The package fails to install due to a missing dependency on
subscription-manager.

Closes-Bug: #1882070
(cherry picked from commit 3784d32d9ceacf0dad8057092752f1ae7be37ed3)

3. CI: Install python deps, mark oraclelinux rsyslog as skipped

setuptools is missing from infra image - so it needs to be installed.

Copy cat of a kolla-ansible change: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/735808/

Disables rsyslog build on oraclelinux (both source and binary) and
tripleoclient (binary).

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/738343
Change-Id: I6068abcbc0e73eeab77b0aa99983a95adc6defd3
(cherry picked from commit d12137ce64fab7e8436aa1c2e32e3bc6ed47c1a1)

commit_message:
Fix multiple issues

1. Fix monasca-grafana by pinning more Ruby gems

childprocess 3.0.0 and ffi 1.13.0 depend on Ruby 2.3.

2. Bump bifrost to 6.0.4

Bifrost had a fix to stop using the master branch of DIB which dropped
support for Python 2.

3. Drop docker-client from OracleLinux sensu-client image

The package fails to install due to a missing dependency on
subscription-manager.

Closes-Bug: #1882070
(cherry picked from commit 3784d32d9ceacf0dad8057092752f1ae7be37ed3)

3. CI: Install python deps, mark oraclelinux rsyslog as skipped

setuptools is missing from infra image - so it needs to be installed.

Copy cat of a kolla-ansible change: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/735808/

Disables rsyslog build on oraclelinux (both source and binary) and
tripleoclient (binary).

4. Stops installing ansible (this is the build part, kolla-ansible has
its own repo and jobs).

5. Use stable/rocky branch for bifrost

Pulls in a fix for diskimage-builder on python 2.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/738343
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/740953

Change-Id: I6068abcbc0e73eeab77b0aa99983a95adc6defd3
(cherry picked from commit d12137ce64fab7e8436aa1c2e32e3bc6ed47c1a1)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-14 13:08:10.000000000', 'message': 'CI: Remove wheels extra-index

pkg_resources installation is failing on virtualenv creation in Xenial with
404 error on downloading pkg_resources from wheel repo,
removing extra-index-url from /etc/pip.conf solves the issue.

Without this change - kolla-ansible jobs launched by kolla changes will not
pass.

Change-Id: I4ba5ab897e44f0fb73aaa3c6248a8f340c9c4cad
'}]
commit_message:
CI: Remove wheels extra-index

pkg_resources installation is failing on virtualenv creation in Xenial with
404 error on downloading pkg_resources from wheel repo,
removing extra-index-url from /etc/pip.conf solves the issue.

Without this change - kolla-ansible jobs launched by kolla changes will not
pass.

Change-Id: I4ba5ab897e44f0fb73aaa3c6248a8f340c9c4cad

 conflict with https://review.opendev.org/#/c/738214/)

commit_message:
[OVN] Fix db-sync-util Traceback when port security not enabled

Change-Id: Id1ed2922a908148b2b271bd28cc974ef424530d5
Closes-Bug: #1882061
(cherry picked from commit 58d1d0dbddd3299537f67b0fdee906918fd4bb6f)
(add newline in neutron/tests/unit/common/ovn/test_utils.py to resolve merge
 conflict with https://review.opendev.org/#/c/738214/)

subject: objects: Introduce 'pcpuset' field for InstanceNUMACell

@Alex, thanks for review.

Regarding if the 'pcpuset' should be a 'nullable' field, I haven't made it being nullable because I copied the behavior from 'NUMACell.pcpuset' field, and regard 'pcpuset' as non-nullable, just like cpuset.
But I do think it might have issue for 3-rd part code out of Nova project, and there is a same issue for 'NUMACell.pcpuset'. 

Anyway, I'd like to change if we are agreed to make it being nullable."}, {'account_id': 30209, 'date': '2020-04-01 11:22:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Alex Xu wrote:

> There are something in hyperv driver should be changed also https://
> github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/virt/hyperv/vmops.py#L482
> -L485

Hi Alex,

I haven't paid a lot of time on the logic of hyperv, so I need to investigate the hyper code since hyperv is also using the same numa topology objects.

I can not see where the problem is in L482 to L485, do you mean I should consider the 'InstanceNUMACell.pcpuset' field also there? Seems it is not necessary, this piece of code [1] indicates hyperV only supports the 'shared' instance and  'InstanceNUMACell.cpuset' is enough to track the shared instance.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/nova/virt/hyperv/vmops.py#L467-L477

Thanks for your review!"}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2020-07-08 09:53:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review+2

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-03-24 14:30:00.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] An alternative way for keeping instance dedicated CPUs

In the preceding patches, 'InstanceNUMACell.cpu_pinning' is
extended to keep the instance dedicated CPUs, in the key, for
the mixed CPU instance.

This patch tries to provide an alternative way for the same
purpose of keeping dedicated CPUs, through adding a field,
named 'pcpuset', to 'InstanceNUMACell' object.

This patch is based on the 'cpu_pinning' approach, so a lot of code
that was added before, not in upstream, is withdrawn.

Try to compare the pros and cons of the two ways and fininally
make a choice between them.

Working in progress. A lot of existing unit tests need to be
cleaned.

Change-Id: I901fbd7df00e45196395ff4c69e7b8aa3359edf6
"}, {'created': '2020-03-26 16:25:31.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] An alternative way for keeping instance dedicated CPUs

In the preceding patches, 'InstanceNUMACell.cpu_pinning' is
extended to keep the instance dedicated CPUs, in the key, for
the mixed CPU instance.

This patch tries to provide an alternative way for the same
purpose of keeping dedicated CPUs, through adding a field,
named 'pcpuset', to 'InstanceNUMACell' object.

This patch is based on the 'cpu_pinning' approach, so a lot of code
that was added before, not in upstream, is withdrawn.

Try to compare the pros and cons of the two ways and fininally
make a choice between them.

update 2020/3/27
This patch makes the existing unit tests and functional tests
passed. But still have several 'MustDo' items should be
accomplished before becomes a patch for review.

But if you like you can find if the alternative works, if it
works then I'll abandom the 'cpu_pinning' approach.

Change-Id: I901fbd7df00e45196395ff4c69e7b8aa3359edf6
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Wang Huaqiang <huaqiang.wang@intel.com>

"}, {'created': '2020-05-15 15:57:04.000000000', 'message': "Introduce 'pcpuset' field for InstanceNUMACell

Introduce the 'pcpuset' to 'InstanceNUMACell' object for
tracking the dedicated instance CPUs. And the
'InstanceNUMACell.cpuset' is switched to keep the instance
'shared' CPUs which are sharing host CPU time-slot with
CPUs from other instances.

This introduced some object data migration task for an
exisiting instance that is in the 'dedicated' CPU allocation
policy with the fact that all the CPUs are 1:1 pinned with
host CPUs, and it requires to clear the content of
'InstanceNUMACell.cpuset' and move it to
'InstanceNUMACell.pcpuset' field.

This patch is based on https://review.opendev.org/714707 and
https://review.opendev.org/714705.

Part of blueprint use-pcpu-and-vcpu-in-one-instance

Change-Id: I901fbd7df00e45196395ff4c69e7b8aa3359edf6
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Wang Huaqiang <huaqiang.wang@intel.com>
"}, {'created': '2020-05-15 16:40:15.000000000', 'message': "Introduce 'pcpuset' field for InstanceNUMACell

Introduce the 'pcpuset' to 'InstanceNUMACell' object to track the
instance pinned CPUs. The 'InstanceNUMACell.cpuset' is switched to
keep the instance unpinned CPUs only. As a result, the vCPUs of a
dedicated instance is tracked in NUMA cell object's 'pcpuset', and
vCPUs of a shared instance is put into the 'cpuset' field.

This introduces some object data migration task for an existing instance
that is in the 'dedicated' CPU allocation policy with the fact that all
the CPUs are 1:1 pinned with host CPUs, and it requires to clear the
content of 'InstanceNUMACell.cpuset' and move it to
'InstanceNUMACell.pcpuset' field.

This patch is based on https://review.opendev.org/714707 and
https://review.opendev.org/714705.

Part of blueprint use-pcpu-and-vcpu-in-one-instance

Change-Id: I901fbd7df00e45196395ff4c69e7b8aa3359edf6
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Wang Huaqiang <huaqiang.wang@intel.com>

commit_message:
objects: Introduce 'pcpuset' field for InstanceNUMACell

Introduce the 'pcpuset' to 'InstanceNUMACell' object to track the
instance pinned CPUs. The 'InstanceNUMACell.cpuset' is switched to
keep the instance unpinned CPUs only. As a result, the vCPUs of a
dedicated instance is tracked in NUMA cell object's 'pcpuset', and
vCPUs of a shared instance is put into the 'cpuset' field.

This introduces some object data migration task for an existing instance
that is in the 'dedicated' CPU allocation policy with the fact that all
the CPUs are 1:1 pinned with host CPUs, and it requires to clear the
content of 'InstanceNUMACell.cpuset' and move it to
'InstanceNUMACell.pcpuset' field.

Part of blueprint use-pcpu-and-vcpu-in-one-instance

Change-Id: I901fbd7df00e45196395ff4c69e7b8aa3359edf6
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <stephenfin@redhat.com>
Signed-off-by: Wang Huaqiang <huaqiang.wang@intel.com>

be "latest".The correct link is [2].

commit_message:
Fix for broken link in Tacker Horizon Guide.

The Tacker Horizon has a broken link for Tacker-Horizon docs.
Present link [1] has a misspelled word "lastest" which should
be "latest".The correct link is [2].

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/tacker-horizon/lastest
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/tacker-horizon/latest

Change-Id: Ifad05db26b8bc390711f2b51aa77b4bb3eb0bb54

commit_message:
migration: Use ansible-inventory to parse tripleo inventory

Instead of adapting to changes to the tripleo inventory structure let
ansible parse it for us using ansible-inventory.

Change-Id: I34ad0fd5feed65dd1266993a77f6ebc69fecfdfb
Closes-bug: #1884764

subject: Default OVN_BRANCH and OVS_BRANCH to latest stable
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-15 10:16:50.000000000', 'message': "Default OVN_BRANCH and OVS_BRANCH to latest stable

If other openstack project uses Neutron with OVN
(as enable_plugin ... neutron) and doesn't specify
OVN_BRANCH and OVS_BRANCH variables in configuration
it will use master branch of those two repositories.

Master branch servers for OVN testing and aligning OVN
Neutron driver with new features.

For now we don't have voting OVN master CI job, to ensure that
everything is fine with it, so we should default OVN for other
projects to the latest stable version that we know works properly.

Change-Id: I6e36ccb8cf4846a1eb11619e7c339a0fc193c4f6
(cherry picked from commit e0e3086b465a91a010b6a21fdd2e70c12f583283)
"}]
commit_message:
Default OVN_BRANCH and OVS_BRANCH to latest stable

If other openstack project uses Neutron with OVN
(as enable_plugin ... neutron) and doesn't specify
OVN_BRANCH and OVS_BRANCH variables in configuration
it will use master branch of those two repositories.

Master branch servers for OVN testing and aligning OVN
Neutron driver with new features.

For now we don't have voting OVN master CI job, to ensure that
everything is fine with it, so we should default OVN for other
projects to the latest stable version that we know works properly.

Change-Id: I6e36ccb8cf4846a1eb11619e7c339a0fc193c4f6
(cherry picked from commit e0e3086b465a91a010b6a21fdd2e70c12f583283)

subject: Add a migration that deletes redundant delayed calls
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 8731, 'name': 'Renat Akhmerov', 'email': 'renat.akhmerov@gmail.com', 'username': 'rakhmerov'}, {'_account_id': 9029, 'name': 'Moshe Elisha', 'email': 'moshe.elisha@nokia.com', 'username': 'MosheElisha'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 12898, 'name': 'Tony Breeds', 'email': 'tony@bakeyournoodle.com', 'username': 'tonyb'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 28522, 'name': 'Hervé Beraud', 'email': 'herveberaud.pro@gmail.com', 'username': 'hberaud'}, {'_account_id': 30755, 'name': 'ali', 'email': 'ali.abdelal@nokia.com', 'username': 'abdelal'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2020-07-13 07:15:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2020-07-13 07:17:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hi,

Is it OK to backport this patch to Ussuri? It adds a migration but the migration doesn't alter the DB schema. It just cleans up a table.

Thanks"}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2020-07-13 07:53:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Thierry, ^'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2020-07-13 08:18:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2020-07-13 08:37:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Renat, I can't help you with your question."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2020-07-13 12:10:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Adding Sean and Tony to the discussion.

We generally don't add/fix migrations in stable branches because there is just no way to force people to run them on upgrades. While it's clear that DB migration is a step when upgrading major releases, it's not a step when upgrading minor or bugfix releases. So you end up with people running the new version, but not necessarily with the latest database.

The alternative is to only ship that migration in victoria, which means that people will have to live with the extra rows until then. Since most users won't run the migration until victoria upgrade anyway, I'd argue the end result is the same, and does not require bending the rules..."}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-07-13 15:46:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Hi,
 > 
 > Is it OK to backport this patch to Ussuri? It adds a migration but
 > the migration doesn't alter the DB schema. It just cleans up a
 > table.
 > 
 > Thanks

Does master (victoria) have this change as well? If someone upgrades from a release without this change, we need to make sure they get to the same state.

We do rarely backport migrations. It's not clear to me that this is a big enough issue to do that though. It's best to avoid it if possible."}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2020-07-14 04:00:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Sean, yes, Victoria has it. No issue here. I don't quite like backporting it just because it's not 100% aligned with the rules. However, some of our users asked us about a backport because otherwise they would have to do the same manually (run an SQL script on their DBs). So this is just for their convenience. The point is that these redundant rows in DB may affect performance badly. So if you are not strictly against it I'd ask for your permission to land it."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2020-07-14 09:03:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

So, the goal is to work around performance issues without waiting until victoria is out, and beyond applying the upgrade, the user has to know about the issue, to take extra manual steps to get rid of the issue (run the migration, despite the upgrade being a stable release).

I feel like giving those users a tool to get rid of the extra rows (or instructions on how to clean up their database) would be equivalent. It would avoid unexpected corner cases due to backporting a migration, or creating a weird precedent for a stable release update instructions.

Basically, if we assume the user has to know about the issue and be willing to take extra steps anyway, I'm not sure telling them "this stable release exceptionally requires a DB migration" is the best way to help them through the change. If documenting the query to run is not user-friendly enough, maybe creating a separate CLI tool for the user to run would work...

Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2020-07-14 10:43:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

User awareness is an argument, I agree. For sure we'd have to tell them "you have to take the latest Ussuri and run migrations again to fix it if you're experiencing performance issues".

Yes, we can give them just an SQL script, of course, but I just feel like a more friendly tool already exists and it's the DB migration mechanism that can be triggered just by a simple command "mistral-db-manage upgrade head" and it's always available on the system. So they don't have to log in to mysql/postgres cli etc. Well, that's not too difficult too but.. I don't know :) I'd prefer to keep all DB manipulations behind more high level interfaces rather than letting user peek into our internals.

But ok, if you don't think it's a good idea then we'll work around that, no problem. I kinda understand that I'm asking something not 100% legal maybe so that's OK if it's not allowed.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2020-07-14 11:59:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

That's just my take on it, would welcome others opinions :)"}, {'account_id': 30755, 'date': '2020-07-14 12:01:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-07-14 12:58:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

So let's say U is the version that is out there today. It may have some performance issues, depending on the size of the deployment.

U+1 can include this that fixes those issues, so it is beneficial for those users that have the problem. For those that have not experiences or noticed the problem, nothing changes.

Future V users will migrate, and the problem should definitely go away by then.

So the worst scenario is when someone has the performance problem and upgrades to U+1, but doesn't know to run the migrations again to get this update. In which case, they are in no worse shape than they were before. And if they come to the community asking why their performance is bad, they can be pointed towards doing this extra step and get fixed up.

I have mostly used sqlalchemy-migrate and not alembic so far, so that's the part I'm not 100% clear on. I would say, as long as if they had upgraded to U+1 and done the migrations again, then are able to upgrade to V and do the migrations again and have no problems having both U+1 and V migrations run, then it sounds pretty safe.

Adding a new tools, while simple, still seems like a bigger risk. So I think that is an option, but assuming my understanding from above is correct, adding a migration that someone might not know to run seems like less of a risk than introducing something entirely new. Or having an operator manually perform SQL statements on their DB."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2020-07-14 16:16:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Yeah, still trying to see if there would be a corner case, but the fact that the code works whether the migration has run or not sounds like it should make it safe...'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2020-07-15 08:27:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Sean, yes, your understanding is absolutely correct. Then I'm going to approve this patch. 

Thanks a lot for this discussion!"}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2020-07-15 09:03:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add a migration that deletes redundant delayed calls

* Due to the bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/mistral/+bug/1861988
  some Mistral installations may have redundant delayed calls with
  the empty "key" column. This patch adds a DB migration that cleans
  them up.

Change-Id: Ic46d3d711a03fbd6364809a0fddcbb48f3e28d2a
Closes-Bug: #1887335

recheck'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2020-07-13 18:48:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 21798, 'date': '2020-07-15 07:53:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

W+1 the full backport chain'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-07-10 13:31:04.000000000', 'message': '[DVR] Related routers should be included if are requested

In case when related dvr router is configured by L3 agent, it is first
added to the tasks queue and then processed as any other router hosted
on the L3 agent.
But if L3 agent will ask neutron server about details of such router,
it wasn't returned back as this router wasn't really scheduled to the
compute node which was asking for it. It was "only" related to some
other router scheduled to this compute node. Because of that router's
info wasn't found in reply from the neutron-server and L3 agent was
removing it from the compute node.

Now _get_router_ids_for_agent method from the l3_dvrscheduler_db module
will check router serviceable ports for each dvr router hosted on the
compute node and will then find all routers related to it. Thanks to
that it will return routers which are on the compute node only because
of other related routers scheduled to this host and such router will not
be deleted anymore.

Change-Id: I689d5135b7194475c846731d846ccf6b25b80b4a
Closes-Bug: #1884527
(cherry picked from commit 38286dbd2e35f1f94bf06b5f1cfa9227e5d402c6)
'}]
commit_message:
[DVR] Related routers should be included if are requested

In case when related dvr router is configured by L3 agent, it is first
added to the tasks queue and then processed as any other router hosted
on the L3 agent.
But if L3 agent will ask neutron server about details of such router,
it wasn't returned back as this router wasn't really scheduled to the
compute node which was asking for it. It was "only" related to some
other router scheduled to this compute node. Because of that router's
info wasn't found in reply from the neutron-server and L3 agent was
removing it from the compute node.

Now _get_router_ids_for_agent method from the l3_dvrscheduler_db module
will check router serviceable ports for each dvr router hosted on the
compute node and will then find all routers related to it. Thanks to
that it will return routers which are on the compute node only because
of other related routers scheduled to this host and such router will not
be deleted anymore.

Change-Id: I689d5135b7194475c846731d846ccf6b25b80b4a
Closes-Bug: #1884527
(cherry picked from commit 38286dbd2e35f1f94bf06b5f1cfa9227e5d402c6)

But if L3 agent will ask neutron server about details of such router,
it wasn't returned back as this router wasn't really scheduled to the
compute node which was asking for it. It was "only" related to some
other router scheduled to this compute node. Because of that router's
info wasn't found in reply from the neutron-server and L3 agent was
removing it from the compute node.

Now _get_router_ids_for_agent method from the l3_dvrscheduler_db module
will check router serviceable ports for each dvr router hosted on the
compute node and will then find all routers related to it. Thanks to
that it will return routers which are on the compute node only because
of other related routers scheduled to this host and such router will not
be deleted anymore.

Change-Id: I689d5135b7194475c846731d846ccf6b25b80b4a
Closes-Bug: #1884527
(cherry picked from commit 38286dbd2e35f1f94bf06b5f1cfa9227e5d402c6)
'}]
commit_message:
[DVR] Related routers should be included if are requested

In case when related dvr router is configured by L3 agent, it is first
added to the tasks queue and then processed as any other router hosted
on the L3 agent.
But if L3 agent will ask neutron server about details of such router,
it wasn't returned back as this router wasn't really scheduled to the
compute node which was asking for it. It was "only" related to some
other router scheduled to this compute node. Because of that router's
info wasn't found in reply from the neutron-server and L3 agent was
removing it from the compute node.

Now _get_router_ids_for_agent method from the l3_dvrscheduler_db module
will check router serviceable ports for each dvr router hosted on the
compute node and will then find all routers related to it. Thanks to
that it will return routers which are on the compute node only because
of other related routers scheduled to this host and such router will not
be deleted anymore.

Change-Id: I689d5135b7194475c846731d846ccf6b25b80b4a
Closes-Bug: #1884527
(cherry picked from commit 38286dbd2e35f1f94bf06b5f1cfa9227e5d402c6)

commit_message:
Creating a new state transition "recover"

Currently recovering baremetal nodes from failure states ("error",
"deploy failed", etc) involves applying the "deleted" transition,
however this is non obvious even to experienced ironic operators.
This change implements a new state transition "recover" which is an
alias for the transtion that is needed to exit the current failure
state.

Change-Id: I34c420bc9052d51c75bf847b64d42d4fe2e5f1b0
Story: 2007646

commit_message:
Define and use octavia nodesets

Jobs on these new nodesets run on nested-virt enabled nodepool provider
nodes, shortening run time by a lot (we've seen a successful scenario
job taking 38 minutes whereas without nested virt could take close to 2
hours).

Change-Id: I3252cb820ebea996ad7f07385793f59c28fbd4d2
